Mrs Irwin to move: That this House: (1) notes that the Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU): (a) is the focal point for global parliamentary dialogue and, as the primary vehicle for strengthening parliaments worldwide, works globally for the establishment of representative democracy, providing an unparalleled parliamentary dimension to international cooperation; (b) at its Assemblies, initiates debates on issues of international interest and concern in order to raise awareness and acWednesday, 22 June 2005 ----Port Adelaide the great honour of launching Ron Ritter’s latest labour of love, Triumph, Tragedy and Port Adelaide, a history of the port. And what an authentic history it is. We all know the cliches about history: to the victors the capture of history, the narrative captures the history, and so on. This history is nothing like that. As I said earlier, it is authentic; it is a labour of love. It is nine years since I launched Ron Ritter’s previous work, Spanning Time and Tide, now sold out at the Port Adelaide Sailing Club. This second book continues the virtues of his first book: authenticity, accuracy, sound research and the presentation of rare photographs. However, it deals with a much broader range of topics, which include the following: the Port Adelaide New Year’s Day regatta; the history of Black Diamond Corner; leisure time activities at Semaphore and Largs Bay beaches; the circumstances surrounding Tragedy Dock; the fire and explosion on SS City of Singapore; Fletchers Slip, South Australia’s first slipway; the 1928 waterside workers strike; the saga of Outer Harbor and much more. On this last matter, the building of the Outer Harbor gave my grandfather Walter, Wattie, a second nickname: the Punt Man. Prior to the building of the Outer Harbor, my grandfather worked for the Marine and Harbours Board. After storms it was my grandfather’s job to recover the punts that broke away from their moorings, and he did this single-handedly in a longboat with oars, oar over the stern. In his book, Ron refers to Sawford’s crew on Native winning the working men’s race at the port regatta in 1895 and my grandfather being beaten by Robert Angelinowich in a dinghy sculling race, oar over the stern, in ketches for a prize of 30 shillings. He would not have been too happy about that. Ron Ritter’s book Triumph, Tragedy and Port Adelaide makes a significant contribution to the history of Port Adelaide. It must be said that a great deal of the history of the port has been lost and that our ancestors did not always record what we would have liked-the quite remarkable history of Port Adelaide. That loss has been addressed in recent years by the Friends of the Maritime Museum in their magnificent publication Port Adelaide Tales from a Commodious Harbour by John Couper-Smartt and Christine Courtney. Ron Ritter continues that tradition. He is to be heartily congratulated. He has researched topics thoroughly for nine years in his spare time and funded his book’s publication in South Australia. Hyde Park Press of Richmond has done an excellent job; and good friend Errol Chinner edited the book. The foreword was written by Brian Samuels, who, more than any other person, has encouraged the written history of Port Adelaide. The launch will most appropriately take place in the South Australian Maritime Museum, Port Adelaide, this Saturday, 23 June at three o’clock in the afternoon. I very much look forward to launching this most invaluable history of Port Adelaide, by a man who has shown again his great love for Port Adelaide. (Time expired) MAIN COMMITTEE

theText: This coming Saturday, 25 June, I will haveReynella East High School East High School, a local high school in my electorate of Kingston, and in particular to make my colleagues aware of a project within the school that will send 10 students to Sri Lanka to assist with the rebuilding process in areas which were affected by the Boxing Day tsunami. The group of 10 students, accompanied by three staff members, will be leaving on 2 July for just over two weeks, returning on 17 July. Three projects will be undertaken by the group. The first task will be making bricks at the Maharagama National Youth Centre. Once completed, the bricks will be donated to various housing projects in Galle. The second project involves working at Lake Maduganga Environment Education Camp. Here students will be clearing tracks, working on simple construction tasks and assisting with the rebuilding of local housing. Finally, the students will be going on a three-day adventure expedition. During the trip, the students from Reynella East will be linking up with students at Nalanda College. These students will then be visiting Australia later in the year as part of a reciprocal exchange with Reynella East High School. The school has fundraised for the trip, and, as part of their curriculum, students are learning about Sri Lankan culture. The trip is being organised through the Duke of Edinburgh’s Award and Ausquest. Students, staff and their families are attending cultural nights sponsored by Adelaide’s Sri Lankan community in their temple at Oakland’s Park. This nation saw a massive outpouring of support for the nations devastated by the tsunami, but it is so easy to forget the tragedy once the news images stop and there are no longer any phone polls seeking support. This school in my electorate still remembers those who suffered and are still suffering in the tragedy on Boxing Day. The school is going to lend a hand in the rebuilding effort. I congratulate the students and staff at Reynella East High School for this very generous effort, and I congratulate their principal, Rob Mutton, on this outstanding effort. It is with great pride that I stand here today as their local federal representative. Baxter Heritage) (9.38 am)-This morning I propose a five-point plan to help with the development of the wonderful town of Baxter. Baxter is a tremendous town. People work hard and retired people and young families live there. In many ways Baxter has not been given the full respect and full resourcing that it deserves. The first of the five points is that we want to work to ensure that there are additional aged care places to meet local demands. Point1 is all about aged care for Baxter. The Baxter village, which has now passed from the electorate of Flinders to Dunkley, does a tremendous job and it has been getting great support from the member for Dunkley, Bruce Billson. I am delighted to be working with Bruce on providing assistance with aged care places for Baxter and the surrounding area. The second issue that I want to raise is about working to deliver additional before school and after school child-care places for Baxter. This town has a lot of working parents, a lot of two-parent working families, and child care is an issue that needs to be focused on. One of the things that I want to do-and we have already been able to deliver some significant results for Baxter Primary School-is to work with the primary school and with any other providers on additional out of school hours care places for children. I think that is very important. The third thing I want to do is look at the facilities for both the preschool and Baxter Primary School. Baxter Primary School is a well-managed school. I think we can work with them through Work for the Dole projects or through other forms of assistance to try to upgrade some of the local facilities. I think that is important. We have already had tremendous success through a formal Commonwealth program with upgrading the facilities at Baxter preschool. But we can go further, and I have already spoken to the leaders at Baxter preschool about that. The fourth point-a critical one for Baxter-is working to upgrade the dangerous BaxterTooradin, Hawkins and Fultons roads intersection. It is a dangerous intersection, and everybody in the area knows it. It is one of Victoria’s principal black spots, and we will keep pushing until this is properly upgraded. This leads to the fifth and final point, that we need to upgrade the train station and beautify it-exactly the same sort of thing that we are proposing at Hastings. Taken together, these five points in terms of aged care, child care, the schools, the roads and the rail hub will all work to make Baxter an even better place. (Time expired) MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Hunt (Flinders
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment andAdelaide Airport Land residents in the electorate of Hindmarsh a great deal of grief. The Adelaide airport land is a large area right in the centre of the electorate, surrounded by about 15,000 homes. Unlike many airports around the world, Adelaide airport is located just six kilometres from the CBD. That is great if you are getting on or off a plane, but for the people who live next door it is not without its problems. Aircraft noise has been an issue for some time, but more recently another challenge has emerged. The land has been made available for commercial development. The federal Minister for Transport and Regional Services last year signed off on a master plan for the airport land which includes provisions for non-aviation related development, including retail, recreational and commercial uses. Because the land is owned by the Commonwealth, it is not a requirement that development on the land comply with state or local government planning laws. The upshot of this is that residents often feel powerless to make a difference when developments that affect them get under way. But the Adelaide airport developments are also creating a very active and aware community, and residents are not taking these things lying down. Instead, communities are becoming increasingly active. There are about six very active residents’ groups around the airport, but today I only have time to mention two. Recently, a group of residents in West Beach became aware that the Adelaide Airport Club would be relocated opposite their homes. Unhappy with this decision, they rallied together and formed a residents’ group. Before long, they came to see me. They also spoke with Adelaide Airport Ltd and with their local councillors and their state MP, the member for West Torrens, Tom Koutsantonis. They have also written to the federal Minister for Transport and Regional Services. I was pleased that Adelaide Airport Ltd, particularly the Managing Director, Phil Baker, was prepared to discuss this issue at length with residents and with me, and he has been willing to request that the club makes several changes to the plans for the new premises so as to reduce the impact on residents. The residents’ group has also collected hundreds of signatures from those living in the immediate area and asked me to table their petition opposing the relocation, which I was able to do earlier this week. The core members of this group have dedicated their time and energy to fighting this decision and to representing the many other residents in the area who would be affected by it. Already, they have achieved much. Efforts are now under way to ensure that the club’s licence recognises the needs of local residents. Another challenge for local residents is that which faces the Netley residents’ group. Whitegoods and electronics manufacturer, LG, has a warehouse on the Adelaide airport land opposite residents. Residents have repeatedly raised concerns about noise at the warehouse, and now the developer, Australand, wants to expand the building. I am told the expansion plans are not consistent with what is outlined in the master plan, and residents have every right to be up in arms about the proposal. In the interests of good corporate citizenship, I believe Australand should think again. Their plan is not within the intent of the master plan, and the residents are far from happy about it. Given the track record of the residents living around the airport, I would advise Australand to bow out early and gracefully, because these residents understand how to be part of a democracy and take action. theText: Lilley Electorate: Detention Centre government’s litany of deception and distortions when it comes to their proposed detention centre at Pinkenba, in the Lilley electorate. I rise to inform the House of the government’s broken promise to engage in genuine consultation with the people of Lilley on their plans to build this unwanted detention centre at Pinkenba and to report on the continuing indifference of the government towards the legitimate concerns of local residents. The government has finally owned up and admitted that it recently bought the Damascus Barracks site in Pinkenba in late May to build a 550-bed medium-security detention centre. This is a significant revelation because it confirms the government’s determination to force a medium-security prison of 550 beds onto an unwilling local community. Since 2001 the government has refused to come clean with the people and to reveal its plans for the site. There has been one deliberate deception after another-one thing said before the election and entirely another thing said after it. There has been underhanded sneakiness of the highest order. During the 2001 election, Minister Ruddock promised that the government had no intention of forcing a detention centre on an unwilling community and that any decisions that would be taken would be taken after the completion of the community consultation processes. They gave residents hope-false hope in the end-that the government would take on board their views. But clearly this was all window-dressing of a decision that had already been made. Two public meetings in the electorate and 90 per cent of residents surveyed voiced their opposition to a detention centre at Pinkenba, but the government’s mind was made up. After the 2001 election, Minister Ruddock wrote to me in July 2002 and said that they would go ahead with their plans whether locals approved or not. So the people of Lilley quickly learned that the government would say and do anything to get them through an election. It was the same old story before and after the 2004 election. Before the election Minister Vanstone denied that a decision had been taken on the centre at Pinkenba, but the budget documents after the election belled the cat, showing that money had been set aside for the project. Of course, this was confirmed when the government purchased the Damascus Barracks site in the last month or so. The people of Lilley will not forget the lies and the distortions of the Howard government when it comes to Pinkenba, especially those local residents who have fought hard against this proposed detention centre, including Margo Canavan, Betty Baldwin and Sandy Spadotto. Now that the government have admitted to buying the site without any meaningful consultation they are one stop closer to building a medium-security prison right within the metropolitan area. Building this detention centre in the middle of a built-up community is simply ridiculous. It is even more ridiculous, given what the government have been saying more recently about the nature of detention. I just do not see the need to continue with a 550-bed medium-security prison for the centre if their policy has changed fundamentally. The government like to pretend that this facility is only for visa overstayers, but there are very few of those each night in Brisbane. This is not some small holding centre; this is a fully-fledged, 550-bed medium-security prison located close to the airport and close to built-up communities. (Time expired) MAIN COMMITTEE

theText: I rise to bring the attention of the House to the HowardCharter Boat Operators fishing operators who are very concerned about the proposed impost of some $30,000 per vessel in annual costs to their chartering operations being determined by the state government. While I understand the need to tighten maritime regulations and introduce a sense of uniformity to national navigational and safety guidelines, the blanket application of these rules without reference to local maritime conditions or safety conditions is draconian and deeply unfair to local business people. The new rules, which are contained within part D of the National Standard for Commercial Vessels, came out of four years of work by the National Marine Safety Committee. This process sought to review and replace the uniform shipping laws and provide an updated framework upon which state and territory governments could base new codes. PartD provides for a national standard of crew competency as well as standards for minimum adequate crewing levels. Most of the charter fishing vessels operating out of the shire do so on a shoestring budget. Often these businesses are operated by people who have retired from their principal job and use their charter business as a way of ensuring they have fuel in their boat and a modest income in retirement. In other cases these businesses are full-time professional careers for residents trying to support young families. Adding between $30,000 and $90,000 to the annual operating costs of these businesses will ensure that most of the small operators will be forced out of business-in the short term and at great personal financial loss. The National Standard for Commercial Vessels does specify a minimum crew, but it also specifically provides for local equivalent solutions for crewing. I put it to the New South Wales Maritime Authority that it is within their power to ensure the continued viability of these local small businesses. When framing these kinds of rules, clauses that provide for a local solution are not inserted merely for fun; they are drafted to provide for specific instances of where risks are lower. In an area like Cronulla, where the boats are operating within sight of land and close to the best rescue facilities in Australia, I firmly support a local equivalent solution. There is no pressing safety requirement for these changes. There have been no fatalities in New South Wales waters which have been the result of a lack of crew. The only recent death on a charter fishing vessel was at Narooma in 2003, when the vessel capsized while crossing Narooma bar. In Cronulla, Botany Bay and Sydney Harbour there are no bars to cross, with deep channel entries to the ocean circumventing these kinds of problems. The New South Wales government and the New South Wales Maritime Authority need to look at proposals from local boat operators in a constructive way to ensure that they do not drive local operators out of business. Ms GRIERSON (Newcastle) (10.00 am)-I am pleased to comment on the committee’s report, which focused on the first public hearing with the Reserve Bank governor since the formation of the 41st Parliament. Importantly, these hearings provide for public interchange and go some way towards satisfying the expectation that, although the Reserve Bank should make its decisions independently of government, monetary policy decisions should have some degree of transparency and accountability, given their potential impact on all Australians. In his statement, the Reserve Bank governor gave an overall picture of the national economy that was somewhat different from the rosy view we get in parliament from the Treasurer. But the main interest is always in the movement of interest rates, and at that hearing it was clearly evident that rates would rise-as they did in March, when they rose by 25 points, remaining at that level since. Significantly, the Governor of the RBA departed from standard practice and expressed concerns regarding some imbalances in the economy. He gave a clear signal to the government that, while monetary policy could influence the interplay between demand and supply to maintain economic growth, only the government could institute reform that would reposition the economy and allow it to take full advantage of the economic opportunities presented. The governor claimed that, without reform to address capacity constraints, infrastructureespecially ports and export transport chains-and skills, the risk of wage increases was high and the ability to maintain commodity and resource export levels could be compromised. Inconsistency in economic indicators was also canvassed by the committee when it was revealed that 2004 GDP growth actually came in at 1.5 per cent, much lower than the forecast of 3.75 per cent. This clearly suggested to some committee members that a slowdown was occurring and that therefore an interest rate rise would not be justified. However, the governor MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: The Deputy Speaker (Hon. Ir Causley)
theText: In accordance with the resolution agreedwas of the view that anecdotal evidence suggested consumption and demand were continuing to increase, and that was worrying to him. Interestingly, the ABS have since revised their retail sales figures upwards for the last years, apologising for their deviation from their usual high standard of reliable statistics. However, upward trends in retail sales, consumer confidence and wage growth had at the time clearly convinced the Reserve Bank that there was a need to dampen demand. The Secretary of Treasury has put forward a conflicting view since the hearing, which is that capacity constraints and skills and infrastructure blockages will not damage the economy sharply-nor, he claims, will they fuel inflation. His confidence in the ability of the market to adapt to these constraints is not surprising, and I think the Port of Newcastle is an excellent example of that. However, it seems that any attempt to apologise for the failure of government to anticipate, plan for and respond to these important determiners of economic success through real reform would be indefensible. At the time of the hearing it was not known to us that the May budget would take on the supply constraint challenges by offering big tax cuts to the suppliers of capital for the economy-the wealthiest individuals, who could be counted on to increase their savings and their investments as a result-while providing very small tax cuts for over seven million taxpayers, ensuring that there would be no inflationary or expansionary impact from the tax cuts. That is the lazy approach to economic reform, matched by some equally ineffectual welfare to work measures and skilled immigration increases. I anticipate that the governor will be asked about that approach to reform when we meet again in August. I attempted unsuccessfully to gain some insight into the normalising of regional data by the Reserve Bank and into how the Reserve Bank responds to divergences in the economy. Now that area of concern has since taken on some very different dimensions. The new divergence evident in our economy is between the states, not just between the regions and the capital cities. Growth in energyand resource-rich states like Western Australia continues to be strong, whilst growth in the most populous states of New South Wales and Victoria is significantly slowing. This is another area for future discussions with the governor. The current account deficit and the terms of trade conundrum will require further deliberations by the committee and the Reserve Bank of Australia. It has been suggested by some analysts that this presents a new dimension in our economy. We now have greater personal wealth, greater demand and consumption, increased ease of access to our markets by other countries, a continuing strong dollar, an exchange rate that favours imports and a domestic supply that does not match our consumption tastes or our demand levels. We are learning that some of the consequences of what some infer is the ‘Gregory effect’ may include continuing unfavourable current account deficits and lower GDP figures-figures which, according to the governor, we will have to become more used to. What must also be mentioned is what was not disclosed at the initial hearing with the Reserve Bank. After the announcement of the interest rate rise in March, public statements were made by some board members suggesting that the decision to increase rates was far from unanimous. This is unusual, but perhaps points to the need for more transparency in the deliberations and decision making by the Reserve Bank. In fact, some members of the committee were interested in the deliberations that preceded the decision by the Reserve Bank not to MAIN COMMITTEE raise interest rates in October 2004, when the housing boom was continuing apace. However, these were not disclosed. The complaint to the AEC by the Reserve Bank regarding the government’s interest rate election advertising material compromising, perhaps, the independence of the RBA was not raised during the hearing. However, clearly we would like to discuss such an important issue, given the importance this country places on separation of responsibilities. In concluding, I thank the Governor and the Reserve Bank of Australia for this important dialogue and express my appreciation to secretariat staff. I thank Bev Forbes in particular, David Richardson from the Parliamentary Library, economists Chris Richardson and Saul Eslake for their assistance to the committee. I also acknowledge the media and community interest-in particular, the presence of many high school students at the hearing. ber for Newcastle, Ms Grierson, noting the large number of school students at the Reserve Bank hearing in Sydney reminds me that many of these school students have a knowledge of economics that would put most professional economists to shame. One of the most challenging experiences I have in my electorate is visiting classes of senior economics students, who subject me to a grilling, the intensity of which I would like to think the standing committee on economics might be able to emulate at some point. In the course of the governor’s presentation to the committee he discussed, as the member for Newcastle has observed, the current account deficit. I wish to make a few comments about the nature of the current account deficit, reflecting on the governor’s observations. The current account deficit is at a record high-there is no question about that-but it is not producing a record high of anxiety either among the business community or the economics community. Some of the reasons for that were identified by the governor. Firstly, we have a floating exchange rate, which is able to absorb the changes in international investor sentiment and the changes in flows of investment around the world. That gives us a great deal more flexibility than we had in the past. Another feature of the current account deficit, or Australia’s foreign debt, today is that it is not denominated in a foreign currency. The vast bulk of our borrowings is either in Australian dollars or hedged into Australian dollars. So in that sense, the foreign lenders are taking the currency risk. That, of course, is an enormous change from previous periods of high current account deficits. There are two other features about the current account deficit today. Firstly, the composition of it has changed remarkably. If we go back to the early or mid-1990s, we see that the current account deficit was composed of a very large fiscal deficit. The government was running deficits. It was a net borrower. Now Labor’s debt has been largely paid off and the federal government is moving to be a net lender. So the fiscal deficit has been largely eliminated. At the same time, in years gone by, Australian businesses were net borrowers; now they are net lenders. The switch that has occurred is with Australian households, which have gone from being net lenders-on a modest scale, to be fair-to being relatively considerably more indebted. That level of indebtedness has caused considerable concern not least to the Reserve Bank, not so much because of its impact on the current account deficit but simply because of the fact that, if households are highly leveraged, they are exposed to greater risk if financial MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Turnbull (Wentworth) (10.06 Am)
theText: The closing remark of the honourable memconditions deteriorate, if income declines due to changes in the business climate or unemployment or if interest rates were to rise. The rise in this household debt has been largely driven by the property boom-some would say the property bubble-and there is a very instructive analysis of this in a speech made late last year by the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank, Glenn Stevens, in which he looks at the change in Australia’s saving/investment position as a percentage of GDP over different periods where there has been an increase in the current account deficit. What is remarkable about the last period, which he sets out as being from September 2001 to September 2004, is that, as in previous periods, there was a decline in savings and an increase in investment-that is what produces the deficit-but the three per cent increase in investment, which consisted of investment in dwellings, was extraordinarily high. So, in the period from June 1997 to March 1999 there was a 2.9 per cent increase in investment as a percentage of GDP, of which only 0.7 per cent was investment in dwellings. In the more recent period, 2001-04, that change in investment was three per cent, of which 1.7 per cent was investment in dwellings. What has driven the change is our fascination with real estate. That is why, in my view, we have seen this increase in borrowings by households, because obviously homes-property-are very easy to borrow against. It is much easier to borrow against bricks and mortar than it is for a business to borrow against its own cash flow. More recently, there have been some signs that the air is leaking out of this bubble and, again, I refer to a recent speech by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, who observed that this slowing in domestic demand, which is taking pressure off the current account deficit because there is less demand for imports, is driven by change in the housing sector. In the last year we have seen a flattening of house prices-in some markets, a decline-a slowing in mortgage lending and, so far, a relatively modest contraction in house building. All that represents a slowing in domestic demand and will, in due course, feed into a reduction in our current account deficit. The opposition have raised the current account deficit issue and sought to criticise the government over it, but, on the several occasions I have heard the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer speak about this issue, I have never heard them identify any measures that the government should take. They have not, for example, suggested that the government should promote a recession in the manner of ‘the recession we had to have’, which was the previous Labor tactic to address current account deficits. They have not suggested we should impose tariffs, I am pleased to hear. But they have rung the alarm bellsPorts seeking to ask a question? issue has been rather like somebody that calls out ‘Fire’ but does not nominate any exits or any measures that can be used to address this apparent emergency. theText: To return to my train of thought, the opposition when dealing with thisresponse for governments when facing a current account deficit has been to put their own house in order and to save themselves. Probably because of a lack of time the Leader of the Opposition was not able to refer to two other factors in that Economist article. They were the remedies or the measures that the Economist urged the Australian government to undertake. What were those? Taxation reform and workplace relations reform. Is the government undertaking those? Yes. Does the opposition support them? No. The Economist, which was relied upon by the opposition in that MPI, also cast its own judgment on Australia’s capacity to deal with this issue. It did so by predicting that next year the current account deficit will have been reduced from somewhere over seven per cent of GDP to around five per cent of GDP-and some forecasters estimate it will go below five per cent. What that very distinguished economic journal was saying was that the economic reform measures that the government should be undertaking to deal with the current account deficit-among other things-are exactly the measures that this government is undertaking and exactly the measures that are opposed by the Labor Party. The Economist cast its own judgment into the future and expected that those measures would be successful. BeforeI accept the question from my friend the member for Melbourne Ports, I make one last observation on the importance of tax reform. theText: Will the member for Wentworth allow a question?member for Wentworth: does he agree with US congressmen who argue that floating the Chinese currency-the yuan-would be a way of handling their country’s deficit and might have an effect on ours. What is your attitude to the floating of the yuan? regret asking it. America has a very different relationship with China than Australia does. America has a wide range of manufacturing industries which are subject to increasing competition from China. China’s competitiveness in the manufacturing sector is extraordinary and, obviously, if the yuan is revalued, that will make, prima facie, Chinese exports to America more expensive. That is obviously what American manufacturers seek. There is a very interesting dimension to China’s manufacturing journey from Australia’s point of view. One of the reasons our terms of trade have improved is not simply because the price of our raw material has increased but because the price of our imports, particularly manufactured goods from China-the world’s leading manufacturer nowadays-have decreased. (Extension of time granted.) China’s ability to produce higher value, more complex manufactured goods, which have traditionally come from higher cost countries, will not only impact adversely on manufacturers in the United States but also benefit Australia’s terms of trade. We will benefit from that because, of course, we are not producing those capital goods and equipment ourselves anyway. is already a big producer of motor cars. There are obviously risks and threats from China to everybody in its domination of the manufacturing universe, but the risks to the United States are considerably greater than ours and the opportunities for Australia outweigh the risks. As China’s manufacturing activities move into higher value products, there is likely to be a continued improvement in our terms of trade both as the price of imports declines and as demand for our raw material exports from China increases. speaker: Mr Brendan O’connor (Gorton) (10.23 Am)
theText: I rise to comment on the reportwell in its proceedings. I would also like to make particular reference to the members for Calwell, Shortland, Swan, Brisbane and Canberra, and the shadow minister for small business, Tony Burke, who also participated. This effort has covered two terms of this parliament. The report had its inception in the last parliamentary term, but much of the analysis and construction of the report, based on the evidence before the committee, was done in this term. So there are a number of members to thank. Along with the member for Deakin, there were certainly other government members who put a lot of time and effort into ensuring that this important committee handed down a very broad-ranging report on increasing participation in our work force. Parliamentary committees are a very important function of democracy and of our system. I am concerned about the revelations that were outlined by the Sydney Morning Herald on Monday and since then-and I understand that they may continue-that have highlighted the failure by government to respond to the majority of committee reports in recent years. I am most concerned about that because parliamentary committees are a reflection of how democratic our institution is. If the findings of parliamentary committees are not properly responded to and respected, it means the parliament is not being respected. I should not have to remind the government that enshrined in the Constitution are not only powers to the executive but also separate powers to the parliament. With the coming 1 July change to the composition of the Senate and the government’s political opportunities in having majorities in both houses, today is a good time to remind the government-in light of the Sydney Morning Herald’s articles on the abject failure by government to respond to parliamentary committees-that they have an obligation, not only by convention but pursuant to the Constitution, to respond to and respect the parliament and not allow the executive to run roughshod over the parliament. I say that because, as the member for Deakin already outlined, there are many unanimous recommendations in this report that go to fundamental issues concerning our economy. Yes, it is true to say that there were some significant areas of disagreement and dissent. Indeed, four members-opposition members, it so happens-felt the need to dissent particularly in areas that went to how industrial relations and disability pensions operate. I will firstly focus upon those areas that we agreed upon, because government and Labor members of the committee agreed on 20 of the 23 recommendations. I want to touch upon a number of them. The committee got it right when it said there was a real need for us to attend to the skills crisis in this country. The committee made some recommendations, firstly by listening to evidence not only from the ACTU and social institutions like ACOSS but from peak employer bodies, who quite clearly said that their No. 1 concern in the workplace was not industrial relations but the skills shortages-the skills that workers need for us to respond to the changes in the economy. We now know that there has been a revolution in the workplace as a result of the changes in our economy as a result of a rapid change precipitated by what is called globalisation. Indeed, the newer economies are growing at a much faster rate than what are termed the older economies. But unfortunately, the government has failed to anticipate the skills required. Therefore, it is brave, wise and proper that not only Labor members of the committee but also government members of the committee point to those deficiencies. Recommendation 2 is: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government in cooperation with the State and Territory governments, industry, unions and educational bodies expand programs to maximise the uptake of MAIN COMMITTEE apprenticeships in areas of skills shortages and ensure that the training is relevant to the apprentices, the businesses and the industry. That recommendation seeks to attend to the deficiencies that we currently experience and to get the executive of the parliament to respond to our concerns. Whilst there was passing reference by the Treasurer to some of these things, we think that what should have happened, if the executive had been listening to the parliament, is that the executive-indeed the Treasurer on budget night-should have announced in the budget in the second week in May some comprehensive response in the area of skill shortages and taken up the recommendations made by opposition and government members in relation to skills. Unfortunately they fell on deaf ears. We do not really believe to date that the government has properly responded to this recommendation or incorporated it into its thinking and its policy. There have been a lot of words spoken about skill shortages but little proper response. The government would be wise to start considering our recommendations in that area. The committee recommended unanimously: ... that the Australian Government establish, as a priority, a dedicated cross-portfolio approach to develop a coordinated long-term strategy, including a series of newly funded programs and defined outcomes, to address national skills shortages. We believe there has to be some proactive intervention by the government to attend to the deficiencies in the economy, to attend to a matter that they have neglected for nine years and to really start anticipating what every other commentator and participant in the economy has already anticipated-that is, as the economy evolves and as the skills mix requirements change, we must be proactive in anticipating those changes. Indeed, I applaud the government members who have come to that realisation, although they had no choice in this regard because they listened to the evidence. The evidence from the ACTU and ACOSS and, more significantly, the peak employer bodies was that employers have major problems in finding people to undertake new work and work that is evolving and developing in our economy. I do want to applaud all members of the committee in finding common ground in that area. I also want to quickly touch upon some other recommendations. There was a recommendation for the government to attend to the effective marginal tax rates. We really believe, again, that this was another opportunity lost by the Treasurer and by the government. It is very clear to us now that the effective marginal tax rates are way too high for lower to middle-income earners. They are effectively an institutionalised, entrenched disincentive to find employment, when you have a combination of taxes and subsidies that could actually lead to people paying 70 per cent and 80 per cent. In fact, there was one situation where the combination of an amount of income, youth allowance and Newstart allowance actually resulted in a 104 per cent tax impost upon a person. So in fact they lost money when they worked. I moved a motion in the House in 2003 on effective marginal tax rates and the need to reduce them. The committee has recommended that that matter be attended to. Again, six government members, along with four Labor members, agreed that the government should attend to this matter so that those people on middle and lower incomes who are in receipt of some government assistance would not be penalised because they seek work. Again, instead of looking to mitigate the problems associated with that matter, the government has decided to ignore the fundamental concern here, give 45 per cent of the $24 billion to 10 per cent of inMAIN COMMITTEE come earners and really not address the systemic problems in our tax system. I do applaud the wisdom, courage and good sense of all members of the committee in relation to those matters. I turn now very briefly to the three areas of dissent that existed. It probably does not surprise you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we did have some difficulty reconciling our views in relation to industrial law, industrial relations and industrial governance. The evidence we heard from a variety of groups indicated a number of things. Firstly, flexibility in the workplace can be achieved in all manner of ways-through temporary employment, casual employment or part-time employment, for example. There are all sorts of ways for any employer with any wit at all to ensure that they have a flexible workplace. Indeed, what we were given by way of evidence was that amongst the OECD countries we have the most casualised work force. However, notwithstanding that, the majority of the committee decided, against the will of the four dissenting members, to recommend that government pursue strategies for further award simplification-by reducing the number of allowable matters and encouraging greater work force customisation. Indeed, they also recommended that the government examine mechanisms to remove barriers to part-time and casual employment in industrial awards and other industrial arrangements. If an employer in this country cannot use the current system in a flexible way then they really have no idea what opportunities they have under the current arrangements. You can employ people using fixed term arrangements, casual arrangements or part-time arrangements. What else is required to provide flexibility? I guess that when government members talk about flexibility they are talking about a one-way flexibility. Their idea of flexibility is really an assault upon the maintenance of some balance in the workplace for workers, who deserve a decent quality of life-and the capacity to balance work and family-and some decency and dignity when they spend so much of their time in their workplaces. Instead, on this occasion government members of this committee blindly followed the ideology of John Howard, Peter Costello and other government frontbenchers and actually contradicted the evidence provided to the committee. Finally, I had concerns about the disability support pension recommendation. We clearly see this so-called welfare to work proposition as a completely bogus proposition. There has been no money properly afforded to this area to ensure that people with disabilities will find genuine work. This is a way of placing people with disabilities-the most vulnerable people in our society-in a situation where they will not have the same amount of assistance. (Time expired) the member for Gorton, the Deputy Chair of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation, on the excellent work he did on that committee. An increase in labour force participation is necessary to deal with the problem of Australia’s ageing population. With an ageing population and a higher proportion of the population not of working age, it is necessary to have more of the people who are within working age actually in work. On that the government and the opposition are in the white heat of agreement. We also agree on the benefit of work for individuals. Work can provide a sense of achievement and a sense of worth. There are few things worse for a community than a sense of welfare dependency. This is apparent in some of the public housing communities in my electorate and other electorates where three generations of welfare dependants live side by MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Bowen (Prospect) (10.38 Am)
theText: I would like to take this opportunity to congratulateside and young people have very few non-welfare-dependent role models. This report is a good exposition of the economic need to increase Australia’s participation rate. I do not agree with all its conclusions, but I do think it has put the case well for urgent action to increase the participation rate. BeforeI turn to Welfare to Work, I would like to talk about productivity and particularly research and development, which this report deals with in its early stages. As a nation, we need to invest more in research and development. I was drawn to the Australian Industry Group’s submission to this inquiry, which pointed out that Australia and New Zealand are the only two countries in the OECD where private investment in R&D is less than public investment. We have seen R&D investment levels in Australia in recent years much lower than they were in 1996, and only now are they approaching the levels that they were at when the Keating government left office in 1996. Personally, I believe this government’s decision to reduce the tax concession for R&D from 150 per cent to 125 per cent to be probably the most backward decision it has taken in the realm of economics. The report correctly highlights the need for more R&D. The committee makes no specific recommendation about going back to a 150 per cent tax concession, but I think the thrust of the committee’s report was certainly heading in that direction. The committee’s work lends itself to that conclusion, and restoring the tax concession to 150 per cent would be logical place to start. On another matter, the report correctly highlights the growing issue of brain drain, of people leaving Australia. Over the last five years, the number of Australian-born people leaving to live overseas permanently has doubled. Of course, many of these are young and welleducated people. There are two ways of looking at this. On the one hand this is a problem which the government and society need to address-and I do not make a political point about this, because there is no easy answer-but there are advantages and opportunities here. I was drawn to a recent report by the Lowy Institute called Diaspora-the world wide web of Australians, by Dr Michael Fullilove and Dr Chloe Flutter. The report deals with this issue of the growing number of Australians living permanently overseas and the wealth of talent and networking that Australians working overseas in very high-ranking positions can provide to Australia, particularly with the trade opportunities that that can create for Australia. The report calls on the government and the parliament to take this issue seriously, to develop those networks and to make it a major goal of our diplomatic corps to have links with the Australian diaspora living overseas. The Lowy Institute report actually recommends the establishment of a parliamentary committee on the diaspora. Whether or not that is a good thing, I am not sure. But it is certainly something this parliament needs to consider, and it lends itself quite easily to the work of this committee’s report-that the government and the parliament need to deal with the matter of more Australians living permanently overseas. On the one hand we need to take steps to encourage them to come back to Australia when they have learned great skills in places like America, Europe and Asia and to contribute to the Australian economy. But on the other hand, while they are living overseas, we need to encourage them to make the most of their experiences and the networking opportunities that are available. I would now like to turn to the major part of this report, which is of course the issue of Welfare to Work. The committee concentrates on the issue of disability pension and parenting MAIN COMMITTEE allowance, and it does this for good reasons. I wholeheartedly endorse recommendation 4 of the committee, which is: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government review the tax-free threshold, taper rates, effective marginal tax rates and income test stacking to maximise incentives to move from income support payments to increased participation in paid work. This was a bipartisan recommendation of the committee, as the deputy chair pointed out, but unfortunately it has not been taken up by the government. The government did not lift the tax-free threshold in the recent budget. Admittedly, it did propose a reduction in the lowest marginal tax rate from 17 per cent to 15 per cent, but this would be nowhere near as effective as Labor’s proposal of an extended low-income earners rebate, which would see the effective tax-free threshold at $10,000 a year. So Labor has taken up the committee’s recommendations; the government has not. In relation to taper rates, the government’s actions have been counterproductive. The taper rate for the so-called enhanced Newstart allowance is 60c in the earned dollar; however, the taper rate under the disability support pension is 40c in the earned dollar at low incomes. So the government has actually increased the effective marginal tax rate for people trying to move from the disability support pension into work. An opposition member-It is disgraceful. the government has not. The government has failed to act to improve the effective marginal tax rates. NATSEM modelling has shown that the effective marginal tax rates of over 60 per cent are a real disincentive to work. Tax rates are more than 60 per cent under the government’s proposed Welfare to Work changes. So, again, Labor has embraced the issue of reducing effective marginal tax rates, reducing taper rates and providing increased encouragement for people to move from welfare to work. This government has ignored the issue. Just this week, we saw the government ignoring a range of parliamentary inquiries and reports, and this is another one where the government had a golden opportunity in the budget to take up the bipartisan recommendations of this committee and it has completely ignored it. The OECD has also identified reductions in the effective marginal tax rates as one of the most pressing needs for the Australian economy. Reduced effective marginal tax rates were an important part of the welfare to work reforms implemented in the United States in 1996 and Great Britain in 1998. These two nations have introduced earned income tax credits, which is one way of reducing the effective marginal tax rate. Whichever way is chosen, the government must take action to reduce effective marginal tax rates. We will not see real welfare to work reform until this happens. In relation to the parenting allowance and the transition of sole parents from welfare to work, the committee also received some interesting submissions. I was drawn to the submission of Associate Professor Austen of the Women’s Economic Policy Analysis Unit of Curtin University of Technology. I endorse her submission. Part of that submission says: ... women’s ability to successfully respond to labour market opportunities, without sacrificing fertility, will depend on support given to them as they try to balance their paid and unpaid working roles. The gender division of unpaid labour; institutional support such as childcare and elder care, and availability MAIN COMMITTEE
