speaker: Mr Bowen
theText: It is disgraceful. Labor has taken up the committee’s recommendations andof parental and other forms of paid leave will be vital in securing both economic outcomes for the nation and the well-being of Australian women. I have said on other occasions in the House just how inadequate the government’s actions have been in promoting welfare to work amongst sole parents. The government has reduced sole parents’ benefits by moving them onto an allowance that is lower than the one they had before. Worse still, the enhanced Newstart Allowance actually has a more punitive taper rate than the parenting payment, with a taper rate for low-income earners of 60 per cent instead of the 40 per cent taper rate that applies under the parenting allowance. Just as we saw with the disability pension, we see with the parenting allowance the government increasing the effective marginal tax rates for people trying to do the right thing-trying to move from welfare to work. Instead of the government encouraging them, as its rhetoric says it does, it punishes them. The government takes an ideological stake and drives it through as it punishes people trying to move from welfare to work. If you believed the government’s rhetoric you would believe that it was trying to help people moving from welfare to work, but what it is doing is punishing people who are trying to move from welfare to work. The government has also clearly failed to create anywhere near enough out of school hours care places to cater for sole parents returning to work. I note that even the Treasury, in its submission to this inquiry, says that women might find it easier to return to the work force with adequate and affordable child care. I would put it a little bit more strongly than the Treasury. The Treasury says child care might help; I think it is pretty obvious that it would help. But even the Treasury recognises the importance of child care. The government has not followed this up with adequate action. There will be 80,000 places created, but there is a shortfall already of 30,000 places. Before anybody moves from welfare to work, we have a shortfall in this country of 30,000 out of school hours places. I make a prediction that the 80,000 places now being created will be woefully inadequate and that the government, perhaps in the budget next year or the year after that, will create more places. It will be forced into action, it will claim credit and say, ‘Look how wonderful we are’, but really it should be creating all those places right now, as people move from welfare to work. Half of the funding for these places does not come online until 2008-09, while these reforms apply from 2006. Even when the extra positions do come online, they will be inadequate. The government will then create more positions, and will claim all the credit, but really it should be doing that right now. The UK government has taken a very different approach to the Australian government. Despite all the measures of support and assistance that the Blair government has provided, it still does not require sole parents to work until the child in question is 16. In contrast, this government has provided hardly any support for sole parents to return to work, yet it requires them to seek work when the youngest child turns six. There is also a contrast when it comes to assisting disabled people to return to the work force. Recipients of a disability pension in Great Britain are also able to access a personal adviser, who helps them develop an individually tailored plan to return to the work force. Government members should take note that, in addition, the Blair government has introduced a disabled person’s tax credit, at a cost of £120 million. Again, this reduces effective marginal tax rates for people moving from welfare to work. MAIN COMMITTEE So this government, in its wisdom, increases effective marginal tax rates, reduces support and pushes people back into the work force. The Blair government reduces effective marginal tax rates and puts £120 million into a personal work force access plan so that each person seeking to move from the disability pension into the work force has a personal adviser to help them work out their travel plans, how to get around on public transport in their wheelchairs et cetera. They get very personal and individually catered support from the Blair government, which still does not require sole parents to return to work until their youngest child is 16. This punishing government, by contrast, requires people to return to work when their youngest child is six. A division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 10.50 am to 11.04 am Blair government’s approach and the Howard government’s approach is stark. To continue that theme, in the area of child care the government of the United Kingdom has taken action to extend child care and out of school hours care. It has spent £330 million to provide out of school hours care for up to half a million people. It has also provided £100 million to improve training for child-care providers, taking all the steps necessary to encourage and support people as they do the right thing and try to move from welfare to work. The early figures in Britain on the number of people returning from welfare to work are encouraging and heartening. It is too early to say just how successful the British government’s scheme has been, but, as I say, the early figures are encouraging. I am not saying that the Blair government’s approach is perfect or that it should or could be adopted lock, stock and barrel in this country. However, one thing is clear: the Blair government has taken the approach that people on welfare often face great challenges in making the transition to work. The government of the United Kingdom has adopted the approach that these people should be helped and supported as they face the challenges involved in moving from welfare to work. The Howard government has taken the approach that the best way to encourage people to move from welfare into the work force is to reduce their benefits and to increase their effective marginal tax rates. Given a choice, I know which model I prefer-and it is not the Australian model, I am sorry to say. This is one of the most important economic issues facing our country. This report does a good job of outlining why it is so important. However, the Howard government’s reforms do not maximise the chances of moving people from welfare into work and they are based on bad economics. I hope the government listens to the alternative approaches, embraces them for the sake of our economy and listens to the unanimous views of this committee, both government and opposition, on the sorts of things that the government should be embracing to encourage people to move from welfare to work. I do not expect the government to embrace the minority report, although I hope it might, but I do expect it to embrace the unanimous report, which it has so far ignored. I encourage the government to do that. Ms HALL (Shortland) (11.07 am)-As a person who served on the Standing Committee on Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation for the entire period of the inquiry this report is about-from June 2003, when the terms of reference were given to the committee by Tony Abbott, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations at the time, right up until the report was tabled in parliament in March this year-I want to put on the record my thanks MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Committees

speaker: Mr Bowen
theText: As I was saying before the calling of a division, the contrast between theto all those people who gave evidence to the committee and to the staff attached to the committee. It was very much appreciated by all of us. We learnt a lot from those people and from hearing about their experiences-the experiences of people within the work force, the experiences of people who tried to obtain work and the experiences of people who were involved in various industries, training organisations and unions. The committee received evidence from a wide range of people. During my contribution today I would like to go through some of the issues that were raised during the inquiry. I have to say that I strongly support the recommendations of the report that were unanimous and those which were contained in the dissenting report. I will spend some time going through the dissenting report later, but I would like to start with the issue of skills shortages. The committee received overwhelming evidence from a variety of people about the fact that there are significant skills shortages within the Australian economy and community. That evidence came not just from one group but from a wide variety of people. Manpower Australia believes that Australia risks economic irrelevance unless its skills shortages are addressed. The shortages occur in a number of key areas. We need to address the shortages in those key areas if we are going to be competitive in the global market, but I really feel that the government has failed to address this issue of skills shortages and failed to address the fact that we are facing chronic shortages in the area of trades. We need to put significant investment into the area of developing and skilling up our work force. We do not need rhetoric. We need action. We need to listen to the messages that we are getting from organisations such as Manpower, Employment Services Australia and the Australian Industry Group. The message has come from a wide range of people that we have a chronic skills shortage in Australia. If we do not address that, we are going to become irrelevant. We need to put significant investment into the area of developing and skilling up our work force. We do not need rhetoric. We need action. We need to listen to the messages that we are getting from organisations such as Manpower, Employment Services Australia and the Australian Industry Group. The message has come from a wide range of people that we have a chronic skills shortage in Australia. If we do not address that, we are going to become irrelevant. I would like to spend some time discussing issues surrounding mature age employees. One of the most disappointing submissions that the committee received, from my perspective, was from Professor Saunders. Professor Saunders tended to write off mature age workers. He was of the opinion that it is a waste of money to try to retrain a blue-collar worker and get that person back into the work force. I find that highly offensive. At a time when we have an ageing population and when we need to encourage mature age workers to re-enter the work force, somebody who puts himself up as an expert says that these men-he highlighted men-are irrelevant. These negative stereotypes that exist in the community affect Australia’s ability to utilise a vital part of our work force. I agree with the Treasurer when he says that we need to get more mature age workers back into the work force. We should value these people. They are a valuable asset to Australia. With ideas like those expressed by Professor Saunders, we will go backwards, rather than forwards. I believe it is possible to retrain mature age workers and that, if we make the proper investment, as a nation we will be rewarded. MAIN COMMITTEE One of the organisations from which the committee received evidence was Westpac. Their evidence was in stark contrast to the evidence that we received from Professor Saunders. Westpac have adopted a policy of employing mature age workers. They can see that this is of great benefit to them. It puts them in a very strong competitive position in relation to other banks. Westpac believe that mature age people relate better to older people when they come into the bank. Westpac are employing mature age people within the client service area. People feel a certain confidence when a mature age person serves them at the counter. Westpac have employed somebody who is in excess of 70 years of age. That is highly commendable. That is the type of approach we would like to see taken by businesses in Australia-not the negative approach of Professor Saunders, but rather the positive approach of Westpac. The level of unemployment amongst Indigenous Australians is a condemnation of what is happening in Australia. All the strategies that have been introduced have failed this group in our community. They are over-represented in our jails and they are well and truly overrepresented in the unemployment figures. For too long the approach to addressing Indigenous unemployment has been to start another CDEP program. It is time we were serious about addressing this issue. Until we do, we cannot hold our head up high as a nation. This brings me to people with disabilities. We received a large body of evidence relating to people with disabilities. The recommendation of this committee with regard to this issue is one that I dissented from. I have a long history of working with people with disabilities, helping them access employment. I spent 13 years working as a rehabilitation counsellor, helping people with disabilities enter the work force. The current proposal and the recommendation put forward in this report will undermine the ability of people with disabilities to enter the work force. The first thing that a person with a disability needs to have before they are prepared to enter the work force or are able to even think about entering the work force is confidence that they will not be worse off. You must appreciate that there is a big risk associated with it. A person with a disability could obtain a job and only be able to maintain that employment for a very short period of time. Once you go over the magic 15 hours a week that is being proposed by the government, it will cause all sorts of difficulties for these people. To be able to assist a person with a disability successfully move from being on a disability support pension or Newstart, you need to have in place a proper program with a proper case manager. You need to have in place all the support that that person will need to successfully make that transition. If you have somebody who is moving from working in a manual occupation and is looking at entering something like a clerical position, you need to make sure that they have the proper ergonomic furniture, you need to have the workplace looked at and you need to make sure that you are not setting that person up for failure. One of the easiest things to do is get the job; it is maintaining the employment that is the difficulty. When I was very new in the position of finding jobs for people with disabilities, I developed a relationship with a number of people who were going through a program. These people were alcoholics. When they were sober, it was very easy to find a job for them. I managed to find employment for five or six of them. Unfortunately, it was only for a very short time that they maintained their employment. One of those people ended up being murdered. Once they found employment they felt secure, they felt that they had money, they felt that they were okay and they were tempted to have a drink, and they did so. The reason they failed was that there was no proper support in place for them after they found that job-at that time. I was MAIN COMMITTEE working as a disability officer with an organisation that only had placement procedures. Subsequently I worked with an organisation that provided ongoing support, and the outcomes were much better. SoI say to the government: be very cautious about where you go with these disability support changes, because there can be very negative outcomes if the proper supports are not in place. It is long-term support that is needed. Unless that happens, we are going to be setting a whole lot of people up for failure. I am sure members on the other side of this House do not wish to do that. I am sure they want to see people with disabilities succeed when they re-enter the work force. The Treasurer said in his budget speech that he would particularly target people with back injuries. Once again, that group needs to have the proper support in place, including the proper ergonomic furniture that I detailed earlier. In the last couple of minutes remaining to me, I will turn to the dissenting report. Recommendation 1 of the committee states: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government pursue strategies for further award simplification by reducing the number of allowable matters and encouraging greater workplace customisation to suit industry and regional conditions. I cannot think of one occasion on which that proposal was presented to the committee. That was not the tone of the evidence we received. The government members took this up and ran with it. We do not feel that casualisation and part-time employment is benefiting the Australian work force. Increased casualisation means less security in the future, which does not in any way benefit workers. If this government is truly about building a strong economy, workers need security so they can plan for the future, obtain housing loans, buy houses and care for their families. This increasing casualisation is not the choice of workers. Some people have been employed for seven years as casuals. (Time expired) Ms VAMVAKINOU (Calwell) (11.22 am)-I am very pleased to speak to the report on workplace participation. I was Deputy Chair of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Work Force Participation during the 40th Parliament but, unfortunately, the federal election was called while the draft report was being considered. As I did not rejoin the committee in the 41st Parliament I was unable to participate in the final presentation of this report, so I am particularly pleased to be given the opportunity to speak to the report today and to thank the member for Shortland, other members of the committee and the staff of the committee for their contributions and their assistance. The inquiry into the long-term unemployed was a valuable experience. The evidence submitted by so many individuals, organisations and stakeholders was challenging, and the inquiry was very much an eye-opening experience for me and my colleagues. This inquiry took place at a time when all the critical issues surrounding employment in this country were being discussed and debated, so clearly the report is current and very relevant. As a result, its recommendations will be helpful to government, to the opposition and to policy-makers alike. I agree with the comments made by the committee chair, the member for Deakin, that the report tackles some of the critical issues that relate to building both the size and the capability of Australia’s work force. Like all other members of the committee, I was concerned to hear evidence that, by the year 2030, Australia would have over 500,000 jobs with no-one to fill MAIN COMMITTEE them. This is indeed an alarming prognosis and, if true, it means we must act immediately to address the looming work force shortage. At a time when alarm bells are being sounded about the skills shortage we are currently experiencing, it is imperative that we address these issues immediately or we will have no hope of averting a potential crisis 10 or 15 years down the track. This report is pertinent, and its importance is also highlighted by the fact that the committee was almost unanimous in its recommendations. Of the 23 recommendations, there was unanimous support for 20, including the recommendations on apprenticeships uptake, on addressing long-term unemployment, on expanding and improving child-care assistance and services and on all but one of the recommendations relating to the disabled. These recommendations are of particular interest to me because they are of great relevance to the people I represent in the electorate of Calwell. I have mentioned many times in this place that my electorate has a large number of residents on disability pension support. We also have a large number of young people who take up apprenticeships because we are fortunate enough to have the Kangan Batman TAFE in Broadmeadows. It should also be noted that this inquiry was undertaken in the context of an ageing population and recommendations 8 and 10 go some way to addressing the increasing issue of mature aged unemployment, which is another significant issue in my electorate. During the hearings, what struck me most was that the evidence being given indicated a strong trend towards ageism in the work force. I remember then remarking that what the submissions were stating was consistent with what many of my mature aged constituents were telling me: there is a real sense of discrimination against you if you are seeking employment and are 40 years of age. If you are 40 and over, you have a problem getting a job if you are unfortunate enough to become unemployed. Many people reported that they were simply overlooked on the basis of their age, with their experience and skills not seeming to carry as much weight as they deserved. These reports have been backed up by figures from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission which show that the majority of complaints before them, in respect of age discrimination laws, claimed discrimination in employment, with 65 per cent of those claims being lodged by men. Equally, many mature aged workers who lost their jobs were low skilled and had virtually no chance of re-employment despite being keen and often desperate to be employed. Given that most of these mature unemployed are simply too young to be out of the work force, it is clear that we need to re-skill this work force and provide incentives to stimulate employment recruitment. Similar problems are faced by the disabled, by Indigenous Australians, sole parents, migrants and the long-term unemployed with a lack of employer interest in giving them a go. If this year’s budget is about increasing work force participation then addressing all areas of disadvantage and hurdles becomes imperative. It is vital that, if the Welfare to Work reform is to be successful, it must tackle and look at employer attitudes and practices and see what can be done to alleviate impediments on that level. Twenty of the recommendations in this report have received unanimous agreement and should be acted upon immediately by the government. The remaining three recommendations, however, have not received unanimous support with opposition members producing a dissenting report covering recommendations 1, 9 and 14 because these committee members have MAIN COMMITTEE substantial concerns about these recommendations. As my colleague, the member for Gorton, has already stated: Our concerns about these three recommendations go to the negative effect we believe they will have on industrial relations in this country. As a former member of the committee, I also cannot support these three recommendations. I stand with the dissenting report of the opposition members for the following reasons. I would like to address recommendation 1 at this point. It concerns award simplification by reducing the amount of allowable matters and encouraging greater workplace customisation to suit industry and regional conditions. Along with opposition members of the committee, I do not support this recommendation because it does not reflect the evidence received by the committee, nor is there any evidence to support the assertion that reducing allowable matters in federal awards would improve work force participation. The evidence received by the committee did, however, suggest that improving award provisions by including provisions such as paid parental leave or job sharing would, in fact, increase work force participation. In accordance with that evidence, I support the proposed recommendation 1 in the dissenting report which recommends that the government pursue strategies to improve participation in the work force by encouraging employment conditions that are mutually beneficial, such as job sharing, permanent part-time and paid parental leave. Recommendation 9 concerns part-time and casual employment and recommends that the government examine mechanisms to remove barriers to the employment of part-time and casual employees in industrial awards and other industrial arrangements. I agree with the dissenting report in not supporting this recommendation as the evidence received by the committee highlighted that whilst there will always be a place for part-time and casual employment there are problems associated with such employment including a lack of training, an inability to save or secure a home loan as a result of being a casual employee, and difficulties balancing home and work responsibilities. I have to agree with the member for Gorton, who makes the very valid point that Australia already has one of the most casualised work forces in the world and a large number of workers in part-time employment. Both groups are heavily represented in my electorate, and I know-because I speak with many of them-that a great number would prefer to have permanent, full-time employment. AlthoughI agree that there is benefit in having flexibility in the workplace that allows for increased workplace participation, this is true only to a certain extent. A great number of Australians, far from feeling that the existing flexibilities provide greater opportunities for participation, are in fact feeling a greater sense of insecurity and underemployment. As such, I do not support this recommendation. Rather, I support proposed recommendation 9 in the dissenting report, which calls upon the government to undertake a comprehensive study on the growth of casual and part-time employment and the social and economic effects of such growth, so as to identify the impact upon industry, occupations, gender and age groups and to identify the adverse social impact on employees and their families. Recommendation 14 concerns disability support pension recipients and recommends that the government introduce increased work capacity provisions in determining eligibility for those in receipt of the disability support pension. We have seen this recommendation incorporated in this year’s federal budget. However, opposition members did not support the recomMAIN COMMITTEE mendation when included in the report, and we do not support the budget provisions which implement the recommendation. Much of the evidence presented to the committee indicated how difficult it was for people with disabilities to gain employment, largely due to the perceived attitude of employers that people with disabilities were not preferred. They were often seen as a burden, with employers often not prepared to pay for the adjustments required in the workplace. Generally, there seemed to be an attitude that people with disabilities were not worthy of long-term investment. Within my electorate are many examples of companies giving disabled employees a fair go, and these organisations include Brite Industries and a local employer, Mr Gary Marshall, whom I have spoken about in this place. He virtually makes it his business to employ people who are most at risk, and most of his work force is made up of people with some form of disability, people with long-term unemployment or mature age workers, who, as the member for Shortland said, when given an opportunity are able to perform tasks efficiently and successfully. It is being given the opportunity that is the problem. There is ample evidence to suggest that there is discrimination in the workplace against people with disabilities and the mature unemployed, in particular. I talk to Job Network providers, such as Distinctive Options, that specialise in finding placements for people with disabilities, and they have an incredible number of problems convincing employers that their clients are worthy of being given a go. So there is plenty of empirical evidence to suggest that it is very difficult for these cohort groups to find employment or to be given an opportunity. I talk to many of these people in my electorate, and they always raise the difficulties of perception and discrimination that they have. It is a real shame, given that in particular the mature aged unemployed have a wealth of experience and potential which, at this stage, remains untapped and needs to be harnessed if we are to avert a skills shortage-the 500,000 jobs with no-one to fill them-by the year 2030. I raise my concerns about the prospects of a large number of people in the Australian work force who are out there ready, willing and able to work should they be given an opportunity, and I reiterate that we need to concentrate very much on employer attitudes. There are recommendations in the report that go some way towards providing encouragement for employers to take on what are, I guess, perceived to be the less desirable unemployed, but I think we are going to require more than just incentives; we are going to require a stick as well as a carrot. If we are going to be successful in the Welfare to Work policy that the Treasurer trumpeted loudly in this year’s budget, and if we are going to arrest the skills shortage and give Australians an opportunity to participate in the work force, we need to be mindful of the fact that employers have a great responsibility to do their part and not to pick and choose as they see fit. After having gone through that inquiry, it is very obvious to me that that was one of the greatest problems, one of the greatest obstacles, in the way of a lot of people getting meaningful and long-term employment. In conclusion, I do agree with the dissenting report that was put forward by my colleagues. I support proposed recommendations 14 and 14A in the dissenting report, which recommend that a broader and more comprehensive study be undertaken and that the 30-hour per week work test for disability support pensioners be retained, given the difficulties I have outlined MAIN COMMITTEE that people with disabilities have in gaining employment and then, as the member for Shortland said, in being able to maintain it. I would like to finish by saying that throughout this inquiry all committee members agreed that paid employment is important in reducing social disadvantage and improving Australian living standards and all members agreed on 20 of the 23 recommendations. What is now needed is for the government to take up the initiatives put forward in this report and to implement the recommendations which were agreed upon unanimously. I thoroughly recommend that the government also adopt the additional recommendations from within the dissenting report. As I said earlier, I think that the report comes at a critical time in the history of employment and the work force in this country. It makes some very sound and sensible recommendations-recommendations that I believe will go a long way to assisting with improving work force participation. In particular, the report goes a long way to assisting those people who happen to be in groups that at present are disadvantaged in the work force to be given a fair go and an opportunity to improve their livelihoods and build upon their aspirations for themselves and their families. Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation entitled Working for Australia’s future: increasing participation in the workforce. I take this opportunity to comment on the recommendations which prompted a dissenting report by Labor members of the committee-a dissenting report that it would seem from the Prime Minister’s recent statement on industrial relations he clearly chose to ignore. Before turning in particular to the three recommendations of the dissenting members, I would like to record my support for the report’s 20 unanimous recommendations. I believe that it is very important that the recommendations that were made by the committeeincluding reviewing the tax-free threshold; reviewing effective marginal tax rates; improving transition to work programs; expanding child care and after-school and holiday care; and improving access to employment programs-should be closely examined by the government if it is truly intent on assisting an increase in work force participation. I also support the recommendations of the dissenting report. It seems to me that the Labor members of the committee have considered the evidence more closely and clearly have a better understanding of the concerns of the average Australian. It seems that the dissenting members of the committee are more aware of the concerns that Australians have in relation to casualisation of the work force. It is true that more employees are facing longer periods of part-time and casual employment. Gone are the days when getting a job meant simply accepting regular, full-time working hours. Some have dismissed this as a change in the composition and structure of work in Australia. Nevertheless, it is occurring, and that fact is certainly supported by statistical evidence. In particular, it is interesting that in the statistics presented in the report the proportion of males employed on a casual basis has doubled since 1988. Additionally, over that same period, from 1988, the statistics show that total employment involving casual employment has increased by 50 per cent. The labour force statistics for April, released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, record that more than 2.8 million people were employed on a part-time basis. Granted, a number of them will be happy to be employed on a part-time basis, as it will enable them to pursue other MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Committees

speaker: Mr Hayes (Werriwa) (11.37 Am)
theText: I rise today to comment on the report of the Standingactivities while earning an income, such as raising a family, caring for aged parents or, indeed, studying. However, many people do want to work more. In 2004, the ABS released a report on the underemployed workers of Australia, which was particularly revealing of the views of part-time employees about their employment status. The ABS conducted a survey throughout September 2003 to provide empirical evidence for that report. At that time the survey showed that 2.7 million people were employed on a part-time basis. Of this 2.7 million people, 23 per cent wanted to work more hours; that is, more than 600,000 people employed on a part-time basis wanted to work more. Examining the data further showed that, of those 600,000 workers, 58 per cent wanted full-time employment and 77 per cent, during the four-week period of the survey, had actively looked for work that would provide more hours. It is pretty clear from the results of that survey that the majority of these part-time workers wanted to work more and they were ready to start working more. The ABS report goes on to indicate that 90 per cent of those who wanted full-time employment were available to start immediately. This situation has not changed. In the lead-up to my own by-election campaign, a constituent in Werriwa approached me and described his experience of entering the work force. The fellow was on a Job Network program and had found some part-time work. As he said, it was great; this was what he wanted to do. This work was probably not the best in the world, but he wanted to participate in the work force. He was very pleased to have gained the job. He sought to inquire of his conditions from his employer. He turned up there and was told that, from the next day on, he would be required to bring his own vehicle because he would be required to travel for work purposes. So he was required to drive his own vehicle not only to and from work but also in the course of his employment. After his first week at work, he had only worked for three days. He said that he was pretty shocked when he got his first weekly pay. After taking into account that he was using his own vehicle not only to travel to and from work but also to run errands during the day for his employer’s business, he found that he was worse off than he was on his former program. So being keen to continue working, he went in the next week-granted, one day was wet-to be told that he would be required only one day that week. The company that he was working for and that he named for me would be well known to everybody; it would certainly be found on the ASX. That is the way in which employment practices are starting to perpetuate-and I am sure that Werriwa is no exception with circumstances like these-and this is one example that was brought to my attention. This bloke is just an average fellow who is happy to pay his taxes. He wanted to participate in the full-time labour market and do his bit in looking after his family. He certainly saw the way in which the system is stacked against many individuals. Given the fact that at the time of the last census one in four workers in Werriwa was employed on a part-time basis, this gentleman’s case that he related to me could hardly be considered as isolated. But it gets worse than that. Not only do part-time and casual workers face greater uncertainty of income; because of their own financial instability they also find it difficult to access a number of other services that many of us would take for granted. Part-time and casual employees have greater difficultly accessing financial services. Due to the uncertainty surrounding their future incomes, part-time and casual employees often report that financial institutions are more reluctant to give them access to loans and lines of credit than they would be had they been in full-time employment. Most of us would know that to be a MAIN COMMITTEE fact. The evidence presented to the committee suggested that casual and part-time employees may also face reduced access to training and skills development opportunities, which are obviously so crucial for people making that transition into full-time permanent employment or trying to pursue a career. I am also quite sure that, if we had a closer look at those who have Centrelink debts, we would probably find that a significant number of those debtors are either part-time or casual employees, as they would find it even more difficult than the rest of us to accurately estimate their annual income. Hence, at the end of the year part-time and casual employees receive yet another setback when they are notified that they have managed to accumulate a Centrelink debt. I guess these are the rewards for being employed under the so-called flexible working arrangements. I would also like to take the opportunity to support the recommendations in the dissenting report concerning employment conditions. Once again, when making recommendations pursuing further award simplification and encouraging greater workplace customisation and flexibility, government members of the committee seemed to substitute ideology for evidence. As someone with a reasonably extensive involvement in the Australian industrial relations system, having worked in it from all perspectives, I find it difficult to believe that further simplifying awards will result in greater participation in the work force. I think such an argument does not hold much weight, particularly when one considers the claim that 77,000 more jobs will be created if small businesses are exempted from unfair dismissal laws-a claim that, when placed under some scrutiny before the Senate committee, was found to be seriously lacking. My views are reinforced by the findings of the dissenting report. The dissenting committee members found that the committee’s recommendations for reductions in allowable matters and greater workplace customisation were contrary to the evidence received. The dissenting members reported: On no occasion had evidence supported the assertion that reducing allowable matters in federal awards would have any bearing upon improving participation in the paid workforce. Work force participation will not be improved through award changes or even the erosion of hard won conditions in awards. It will not be improved by exempting small business from unfair dismissal laws or reducing the right of entry into workplaces. And it will not be improved by effectively sidelining the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, which, after all, has acted as the independent umpire looking to protect the interests of both employers and employees engaged under the system. Increasing participation rates requires increasing opportunities for unemployed people to enter the work force. These opportunities will only emerge when the hurdles that people face when they are seeking a job are effectively addressed. To address those issues really does require us to focus on matters such as the effective high marginal tax rates; child-care places, so that they are more abundant to facilitate people being able to translate into the workplace; and more affordable training places, when the opportunities are there, for people to become job ready to re-enter the work force. I have spent many years working closely with both employers and employees in business improvement programs and also representing workers as a union official. Bearing in mind this experience, I cannot recall one occasion when I thought that the employment prospects of MAIN COMMITTEE Australians would be enhanced by reducing award conditions or by reducing the number of allowable matters. I am yet to be convinced that Australians who for whatever reason are not participating in the labour market at the moment believe this will encourage them to re-enter the labour market. The Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education References Committee recently explored the stunning statistic this government used to justify excluding small business from unfair dismissal laws-that is, that small business will create 77,000 new jobs if exempted from unfair dismissal laws. The assertion was found to be unreliable and based on opinion and perception rather than on any accurate data. In much the same way, once the claim that reducing the number of allowable matters and increasing the flexibility in workplace arrangements is subject to some harsher scrutiny, I suspect that it will be found to be lacking as well. With regard to the recommendations on disability support pensions, I support the expansion and modification of the Job Network disability support pension pilot. (Time expired) Ms HOARE (Charlton) (11.52 am)-This report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation titled Working for Australia’s future: increasing participation in the workforce was tabled in the House of Representatives on 14 March 2005. AlthoughI was not a member of this committee, I understand the importance of its findings and its recommendations to future work force participation in this country, particularly the participation of older workers and other disadvantaged groups. We are all aware that no longer do any of us have a career for life. Many Australians will have two, three or more careers over their working lives. I note that the committee was told that by 2030 Australia will have over half a million jobs with no-one to fill them. I note also the committee’s determination, in the face of low unemployment levels, to assist the work force participation of those groups who have traditionally been called disadvantaged. These groups include Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, the long-term unemployed, young people, migrants, mature age workers and people with disabilities. This report recommends that these people should be assisted by government and that this assistance must be targeted and delivered in an appropriate way. Some members in this place may know that in my previous career I was a manager with the old Commonwealth Employment Service. I came into the CES at the time when Paul Keating’s Working Nation programs were being implemented. This was exactly the range of programs which case managed so-called disadvantaged job seekers to increase their work force participation. Under these case management programs, there was a range of programs to assist the long-term unemployed, people with disabilities, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, and sole parents. There was a whole spectrum of programs. Whatever level a job seeker was at, there was a program that they could fit into and that would take them right through to the reality of getting a job. These programs included, at one end of the spectrum, training programs to assist people with literacy and numeracy skills and programs to increase self-esteem and to address personal issues that related to working. Along the spectrum were skills training and eventually to what were known then as job clubs, where people were assessed as being work ready and MAIN COMMITTEE were assisted in applying for jobs-in getting their CVs together and in the actual physical activity of getting out there, knocking on doors looking for work. Other programs included the Jobs, Education and Training program, which assisted sole parents. That program was delivered between the CES and the then department of social security. It provided a lot of assistance for sole parents to assist themselves into the work force, including subsidies for child-care arrangements. I believe that program still exists, but it has been decimated under the Howard government. There was training for Aboriginal people, which was the specific area that I was working in. There were a whole range of programs to assist particularly young Aboriginal people into work. I had the satisfaction of seeing many young Aboriginal people commence and complete traineeships and apprenticeships and get themselves into work. There were also programs called disability support panels. These panels case managed each individual with a disability personally to assist that person into a job. The panels consisted of somebody from the CES, somebody from the department of social security and somebody from the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service. Those people would then also go out and assist people to sell their skills to employers and actively encourage employers to take these people on. I want to make a point in relation to work force participation of Indigenous Australians. There are seven pages in the report, from page 151 through to page 157, which deal with participation in the work force by Indigenous Australians. However, there does not seem to have been a recommendation from the findings of the committee relating to Indigenous employment. The committee did note on page 154: While significant numbers of Indigenous youth are being helped to gain employment through Job Network and the Indigenous Employment Programme ... more needs to be done to ensure they have the skills, job search techniques, confidence and motivation to benefit from strong economic growth. The report went on to say at 5.101: The Committee is encouraged by the broad range of these initiatives and the improvements in employment outcomes. However ... significant focus is required to support and foster further increase in participation in paid work. I find it a bit disturbing that, although there had been some focus on Indigenous employment participation, there were no recommendations coming out of this report. As I said, the programs that had been in place in the old CES under Paul Keating’s Working Nation were either abolished or decimated on the election of the Howard government in 1996. I want to move now to changes proposed in this year’s budget to the disability support pension. I note the recommendations relating to these changes were dissented from by the Labor members of this committee. The dissenting committee members noted: ... that while the Job Network Disability Support Pension pilot has shown some promise in assisting people on the DSP to gain employment, there are areas which require greater investigation before any long term conclusions can be made. The dissenting members also said: Less than half of the pilot participants and less than a quarter of DSP recipients who initially met the providers were successfully placed in employment or education. If this sample is representative then MAIN COMMITTEE more than half of the DSP population could be penalised by the proposed changes to the DSP eligibility requirements despite their desire to look for work. The concerns that we have in the Labor Party in relation to the changes to the disability support pension have been expressed in this place. They include concerns about the changes in the eligibility criteria-that is, eligibility for a person who has a disability will be changed so that the number of hours a person is deemed as able to work without losing eligibility will be reduced from 30 hours a week to 15 hours a week. From1 July next year we are going to see two classes of disability support pensioner. We are going to see those people who are on the disability support pension who cannot work more than 30 hours a week but may be able to work between 15 and 30 hours a week and those people with a disability who will be forced onto Newstart allowance because they have been assessed as being able to work more than 15 hours a week. These people are also going to see a drop in their incomes. Once we have a person with a disability who is deemed to be able to work more than 15 hours a week, rather than being supported by a disability support pension where all the support mechanisms are in place for that person-as well as assistance in concessions and a little bit more income-they are now going to be forced onto Newstart allowance. They are going to have lower incomes than disability support pensioners, but they are going to have the same health concerns and they are going to need the same assistance in trying to look for work as they would if they were on the disability support pension. Those people with disabilities who can work more than 15 hours a week are being told, ‘Yes, you must look for work,’ but they are also being told ‘You are not going to get the same support as a disability support pensioner to look for work and you must do it on less money.’ We must remember that people with disabilities or chronic illnesses have variances in their day-to-day lives. They can have good weeks and bad weeks and good months and bad months. This particularly applies to people with mental illnesses. If a person with a mental illness who is assessed as being able to work more than 15 hours a week, subject to the work activity test, goes off and gets themselves a job that they can do, the next week or the next month they might have a bad week and not turn up for work. That person is then going to be penalised when they go back to the Centrelink office to resume their unemployment benefits. They will be penalised for leaving a job. But they have left a job through no fault of their own; they have done that because they have a particular illness which has not been catered for under these arrangements. A lot of these people would be working if they could be working. If there were jobs out there that were for 15 or 20 hours a week, with flexibility and arrangements to adapt to their health circumstances, it would be great. But the unfortunate reality for a lot of the people with disabilities who want to work is that the jobs which should be flexible to their needs just do not exist out there. I want to move on now to the long-term unemployed and particularly the mature long-term unemployed. We saw in April the release of the Productivity Commission’s report on the economics of ageing. Following the release of that report, Sid Marris, in the initial paragraph of an article he wrote in the Australian, said: The first priority for tackling the mounting taxpayer costs of ageing should be getting unemployed mature workers into a job rather than simply raising the pension age. MAIN COMMITTEE The Productivity Commission’s report was titled Economic implications of an ageing Australia. The summary released with that report stated: People aged over 55 years have significantly lower labour force participation rates than younger people. As more people move into older age groups, overall participation rates are projected to drop from around 63.5 per cent in 2003 04 to 56.3 per cent by 2044-45. Following the release of that report, a couple of statements were made. An article headed ‘Work for over-55 jobless the key’ in the Australian of Wednesday, 13 April 2005 states: Council on the Ageing-National Seniors chief executive David Deans said that with work force participation for men aged over 55 below 50 per cent in Australia, a low figure by international standards, mature-age workers and employers had to think differently about work and training. That is also reflected in this report. The article later states: Combined Pensioners and Superannuants Association NSW president Morrie Mufsud said ... increasing the pension age to 70 or 75 was inhumane and would put greater stress on the health of older people. Over the years that I have been representing my constituents of Charlton here, I have received much correspondence regarding the barriers facing long-term unemployed, mature age workers when trying to get back into the work force. I have one such letter here, written by Graeme Winter and signed by nearly 40 constituents, parts of which I would like to read into the Hansard. These quotes touch on just some of the barriers and challenges that face mature age workers. Graeme writes: Dear Madam, As a person over 45 years and looking for work, I am writing to make you aware of the challenges faced in my area. Canberra and Little Johnny and his team have got to think of the age group who left school before 1980 and did not do well at school, and in a lot of cases, as far as computers go, we did not have any. … … … These days, with our age group all you have are the newspapers and going to Centrelink and playing with the touch screens ... they don’t seem to want you. You are hard pressed to find jobs for people from thirty to forty-five, then after that it just gets even harder. That is also for all the jobs in the paper and with all of them you need certificates and other tickets and ... it can cost you one hundred to a thousand dollars. … … … Transport in this area is and always has been a problem. … … … I know a lot of people like me who have only had 1 to 5 months work at a time ... and have a very hard time because of our work history but it is because a lot of the places go broke or just get rid of us for someone younger. If something is not done soon by Little Johnny and his party about us 45 years and older age bracket there are going to be more and more of us out there in nowhere land just getting older and more depressed and not having much of a future and again that affects our health and costs more money on health benefits. Graeme’s letter concludes by saying: SoI just think we need a fair go and work that is 30 hours a week and more otherwise we will never get off the unemployment benefits. Ms OWENS (Parramatta) (12.07 pm)-This report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation is indeed a very welcome report. I would like to start by congratulating the members of the committee on both sides for what is an extremely substantial and much needed report. I particularly congratulate the members of the government, who have contributed to an analysis of the current situation in Australia which is quite often critical of their own government. There are two issues in my electorate which are regularly raised with me. The first concerns unemployment. In spite of the rhetoric about low unemployment, one of the most common issues raised with me concerns people unable to find a job. Whether it is single mothers, mothers returning to the work force, people with disabilities, older Australians, skilled migrants or members of the Indigenous community, the difficulty in finding work is still very much alive in my electorate in spite of the rhetoric about low unemployment. The second issue which is regularly raised is raised by the small business community in particular, and in my electorate that is a vibrant community indeed. The issue for them concerns future growth. It concerns the ability to find skilled people to work for them. It involves the need for greater investment in research and development and for the building of export markets. This report contributes greatly on both of those issues. I have learned a great deal from reading it, and I know I will find it extremely useful in working with people in my electorate. It is a comprehensive and serious report involving over nearly 100 submissions and over 20 days of public hearings, and again I thank the committee, particularly on the government side, for the courage to be constructively critical of the government. Many of the recommendations imply a failure by the current government to seriously tackle issues of workplace participation, particularly in the areas of skill shortages and marginal tax rates. But it is interesting to note that when committee members from both sides of the House get together and have a proper look at what is happening there is general agreement on what needs to be done. Of the 21 recommendations, the vast majority were passed unanimously. That is a very good sign of the health of our democracy when people get together and work collaboratively. We have a comprehensive report making largely unanimous recommendations which was tabled at the beginning of this year and yet, in spite of its quality, those recommendations were not incorporated in the budget. On occasion the Treasurer referred to some of the issues, but it is fair to say that he did not pick up the main recommendations of that report. This is indeed a lost opportunity. The members of the committee, and the members of the public who contributed to this inquiry, made an extraordinary effort in putting this report together and their work deserves much more consideration than it received. It is interesting to speak on this report now, after the budget, when it was actually written before the budget because it throws the budget into an interesting light. speaker: The Deputy Speaker ( Mr Wilkie)
theText: BeforeI call the honourable member for Parwere not addressed adequately in the budget-and nor, for that matter, was the whole issue of how we get Australians back into the work force. Instead of taking the positive approach recommended in this report in the main the government took a punitive approach-a stick approach-to forcing people back into the work force. It is clear from the recommendations in this report and the substance of the report that there are far greater barriers to people returning to the work force than a willingness to do so. There is a recognition in this report that employment is patchy, a recognition that I really appreciate having spoken to so many people in my electorate who are having difficulty getting back into the work force. It clearly recognises that, while we can talk about the overall low unemployment rate, that rate is not enjoyed by some sections of our community, particularly the Indigenous community, women, older Australians, younger Australians and skilled migrants. I would like to raise a couple of examples that have come up in my electorate recently of people who are facing extraordinary barriers to their re-entry into the work force-barriers which this report addresses but which the government has failed to address in the budget. My first example is of a 29-year-old woman who emailed me a couple of days ago. She is married and has three children between eight months and six years old. She is a stay-at-home mum. Before she decided to stay home with her children she was quite a senior person in the public sector. She resigned from her full-time job in July 2004 to be a full-time stay-at-home mum. Since then, she and her husband have reviewed their financial situation and decided that she needs to return to full-time work. They have a mortgage and a car to pay off and their wage is barely making ends meet so they feel that she needs to return to work. She does not have anybody to help with looking after her children-she does not live close to her parents, for example-so she needs to send one of the children to beforeand after-school care and two of the children to full-time long day care while she returns to work. She went to Centrelink with an estimated income of $95,000 to calculate the family’s childcare benefit and family tax benefit. After she considered those and took into account childcare costs, which would be $95 a week for one child and $185 a week for each of the otherstotalling $515 per week-she realised that child care would cost $27,000 per year. That would be more than 70 per cent of her pay and larger than their mortgage payment. She then went on to calculate their net weekly income less their expenses and realised that if she returned to work she would be $50 a week better off than if she did not. After taking into consideration the effect that returning to work would ultimately have on her relationship with her children and the pressures it would have on her marriage, she just cannot justify returning to work for $50 a week. The budget announced that there would be 80,000 extra child-care places but, as she says, that is no use if the price is not regulated. In her area long day care is charged at $57 a day for under twos and $47 a day for children aged two to six. With three children, that is not something she can afford. This woman asks in her email what incentive she has to go back to work, even though she wants to. She has discussed this issue with other mothers in her area and has found it to be a common story, as have I in visiting child-care centres around my area. The single biggest topic of conversation among mothers, both those working part time and those staying at home, is the difficulty they have in finding a way back into the work force. The second example I have is of a young woman I know who has a mental illness. She is bipolar. She is an extraordinary young woman and was highly skilled before the onset of her MAIN COMMITTEE illness. She has been on the disability support pension for quite some time. Through the intervention of a small group of people, she has managed over the last four or five years to find her way back into the work force on a part-time basis, and she is now managing to control her illness. She has not had a serious bout of depression and has not needed shock therapy for nearly 2½ years. She is now looking at a situation where she is able to work more hours and can get the work. But, of course, if she does that she will have to go off the disability support pension. This should be a time of great rejoicing for this woman. She has been on that pension for many years now and, through considerable work by her and a surrounding group of supporters, she has found a way back into the work force and has taken back control of her life. She should be celebrating. Quite to the contrary, she has a recommendation from her psychiatrist that she not take up this option at this time, for the simple reason that if she does go back to work and then lapses back into her illness-which undoubtedly she will; this is a lifelong illness that she has-and has to return to the disability support pension at some point, she will go onto the new pension, not the old one. She also may not be able to get back onto it because of her capacity at this stage, when her illness is essentially under control, to work considerably more than 15 hours a week. Because fear of the future is one of the triggers for this woman’s illness, her psychiatrist’s advice is that she will be better off in the long term working only a few hours a week, rather than doing the considerable hours that she can. When you understand that this woman is one of the leaders in the field-that when she does work she is an unbelievably productive person who makes a great contribution to those around her-it is really quite a tragedy. This is a case of a person who is ready to return to work and really should be returning to work, but the very measures which the government introduced to try to force her to do so are those which will prevent her from returning to the work force. The third example is mothers returning to the work force. I have just given part-time work to two mothers who are returning to the work force after a long time, and I would encourage every employer out there to consider finding a way to get some of these fabulous mothers back into the work force. For a start, they are quite often more mature women who have had experience in the work force at a very high level and who are looking for secure, ongoing work at a level which allows them to go home at the end of the day and concentrate on their family. They are those rare workers who bring skills to a job they can quite often handle easily. They do that job with their full attention and go home at the end of the day to concentrate on something else. They are incredibly valuable people. WhatI have found in talking with these people and the many who come to my office looking for a solution to their dilemma is that they have difficulty in finding work which allows them to balance their responsibilities to their families. There is difficulty in finding work, for example, which while secure and ongoing provides time off during school holidays. It is difficult to find work close enough to their own home to be able to get to and from work, and to include travel time, between the hours of nine and three. This report makes quite a few recommendations concerning child care. Child care is absolutely essential to these women. It also covers in some depth the area of family balance, which is one of the biggest barriers for women returning to the work force. Again, the budget which was recently delivered does not address this issue in any real way at all. We still have in our MAIN COMMITTEE community thousands of women with great skill and great willingness to return to work who simply cannot find appropriate working conditions in which to do so. The casualisation of the work force is an increasing barrier to these women. I met two parents recently when I was doorknocking in the south of my electorate. The first time. I went to their house I did not actually meet them; I encountered their six-year-old child at home on her own. She-and this is quite scary to me-opened the door to me, and I suspect she would have opened the door to anyone who knocked. There was a six-year-old child at home on her own. SoI phoned these parents after hours, just to see how they were and if they needed some help, and I found two people who got up every morning not knowing whether they were going to work that day-two parents on casual work in a low-skilled area who phoned the office each morning to find out whether they were going to work. They were on extremely low pay and under very poor conditions with three children, actually, under the age of 10, all three of whom were at various times at home on their own. These parents did not have a support network that could help them. These parents did not have the opportunity to find regular child care; in fact, child care does not work on that kind of basis. They really were doing the best they could. They were doing their best to pay their rent; they were doing their best for their children. Unfortunately, the best is still an appalling situation for these parents. Not only could they not guarantee that their children could be picked up at school; as a married couple, they could not even commit to each other that they would be there on Saturday to pick up the kids from soccer or that they would take care of the kids tomorrow. These were two people who were completely unable to make the commitments to each other that parents need to make in order to stay together, let alone raise three children. The recommendation in this report that even suggests increasing the casualisation of the work force is an appalling recommendation for people who live this kind of lifestyle now. Anybody, any parent-any person, really-seeking to save for their retirement, to educate their children or seeking to build a life needs some form of planning in their life. You simply cannot commit to a family and children and a future if you cannot look ahead and know that you can earn this amount of money, that your pay will come in on a regular basis, that your job is reasonably secure-even if irregular-and that you can commit to the people around you to do the things you need to do to hold your relationships together. The casualisation of the work force is not just about work force and it is not just about business. It is actually about family. It is an extremely negative trend that has made it incredibly difficult for people who are already struggling with low wages and poor conditions and, in many cases, a low education level, to build lives for themselves and their families.
