speaker: Mr Keenan (Stirling) (12.23 Pm)
theText: I rise to continue my comments of condolence onbate was adjourned. I had been talking about the Pope’s life during World War II, which was extraordinarily hard in his native Poland. During that time he had become a priest and he had earned his first doctorate. He continued his studies and in 1953 he defended his thesis and was appointed a professor of philosophy at the University of Cracow. The following year he joined the faculty of the Catholic University in Lublin. He moved through the ranks of the Catholic Church swiftly. In 1958 he was named the Auxiliary Bishop of Cracow and in 1964, when the communist government lifted a ban on such appointments, he was promoted to archbishop. He was promoted to cardinal in 1967 by Pope Paul VI. As a cardinal, he was required to attend in Rome at the untimely death of Pope John PaulI who, as we all know, died after just 34 brief days in office. On 16 October, after three days of deliberations in the Vatican Sistine Chapel and after eight ballots, Wojtyla was elected to the throne of St Peter. At 58 he was the youngest pope in 132 years. ‘It is God’s will,’ he declared when the vote was announced, ‘I accept.’ With those simple words, he began one of the most extraordinary reigns of any pope, creating a legacy that touches all parts of the globe. Pope John Paul II led the world’s Catholics for 26 years, which is the third longest reign of any pope. His capacity to travel was one of the hallmarks of his period in office. He transformed what was traditionally a Eurocentric church into one with a global outlook. His destinations included the United Nations, remote islands in the farthest reaches of the Pacific, the plains of Africa, the slums of Latin America and the Mall in Washington. His visits included non-Catholic areas such as India and South-East Asia. His extensive travels made him one of the most recognised figures in the world. I well remember going to the local racetrack in Perth when the Pope visited and I can remember him walking by and greeting the assembled children, to our great excitement at the time. He drew enormous crowds on his two Australian visits, and these crowds were repeated wherever he went in the world. No corner of the world escaped the Pope’s attention, and his popemobile was a very familiar sight on the evening news. On his travels he reached out to men and women of other faiths. Indeed, he did more than any other pope to open dialogues with other religions. He was the first pope to enter a mosque and the first pope to visit a synagogue. He championed relations with the Jewish community, and one of his first official acts was to send a message to the Jewish community in Rome. Under his guidance, the Vatican opened full diplomatic relations with Israel. The process of reconciliation reached a dramatic climax during the Pope’s visit to the Holy Land in March 2000. At Yad Vashem, Israel’s monument to the Holocaust victims, he declared: ... I assure the Jewish people that the Catholic Church, motivated by the Gospel law of truth, and love, and by no political considerations, is deeply saddened by the hatred, acts of persecution and displays of anti-Semitism directed against the Jews by Christians at any time and in any place. In Jerusalem, Pope John Paul II prayed at the Western Wall, the most sacred site in Judaism, and he also visited the Dome of the Rock and the al-Aqsa Mosque, the third holiest site in Islam. I note that the Chief Rabbi of Rome, who once prayed with the Pope, has said that he believes that Pope John Paul II ushered in a new era of Jewish-Christian relations. I also note that following the Pope’s death he was eulogised by both the Israelis and the Palestinians and that the President of Israel and the Prime Minister of the Palestinian Authority both attended MAIN COMMITTEE his funeral. I know that sadness over the death of Pope John Paul II was shared by both Jewish and Islamic communities in my electorate of Stirling. Perhaps the real defining moment of his reign as Pope was in the role that he played in liberating the people of Eastern Europe from the forces of totalitarianism. He worked tirelessly with the people in his native Poland, in Hungary, in what was then Czechoslovakia and in other nations that were locked into the rigid sphere of Soviet domination. He visited Poland not long after he was elected Pope, in June 1979, and that was his second overseas visit. He received a rapturous welcome from Poles across the whole country. He used his visit to highlight the plight of the Poles, and he developed close ties with the Solidarity movement and a man who would be Poland’s first post-communist president, Lech Walesa. He is reported to have told a Polish cardinal after his election as Bishop of Rome, ‘I have become the Bishop of Rome but I have not ceased being a Polish bishop.’ The Pope visited his homeland eight times during his reign. These visits increased the confidence of the Polish people and ultimately contributed to their throwing off the yoke of communism. This in turn contributed to the extraordinary demise of this evil doctrine in Eastern Europe and in the Soviet Union. With hindsight, I often fear that we forget how souldestroying communism was to the people who were literally trapped behind the Iron Curtain. Pope John Paul II, by his presence and quiet dignity, challenged those regimes to respect the dignity of the people that they ruled over. By visiting these nations he was able to highlight the deficiencies within the governance of these countries and to shine a bit of light into corners of the world where information and hope were not readily available. I am reminded of the quote attributed to Stalin, ‘How many divisions does the Pope have?’ Of course, the Pope had no armies but he did have the power of his own ideas and I think that history has proven him to be the victor in that particular conflict. Pope John Paul II was a man of very firm beliefs. He did not gauge the prevailing view before making up his mind but decided what was right and then stuck to it. This is in marked contrast to some of the more fashionable clerics who seem to be more malleable in their views. In fact, I am often struck by how some members of the clergy now seem prepared to jump on whatever politically correct bandwagon happens to be passing. Even in death, many have criticised Pope John Paul II for the rigidity of his views-and I had better add that I do not share them all-but I respect the fact that he remained true to what he believed was right. I heard a person who was randomly interviewed at the time of the Pope’s death make a comment that went something like this: ‘I’m not what you would call a true believer, but I believed in him.’ This person, in one simple statement, was able to express exactly what it was that made Pope John Paul II so special. He was a man who was able to gain the love and respect of not only people of Catholic faith but people of all religions across all nations. His presence and counsel will be missed by many. His recent funeral will be recorded as one of the most memorable events of this century for two reasons: firstly, the unprecedented outpouring of public grief and, secondly, the sheer number of world leaders that attended. I cannot think of any other event that would have brought such a diverse group together. It will be recorded as one of the defining moments of its time. MAIN COMMITTEE I would like to conclude my remarks by congratulating Pope John Paul II’s successor, Pope Benedict XVI. I am sure that the whole parliament will join me in wishing him well in carrying out his extensive duties on behalf of Catholics the world over. Ms BURKE (Chisholm) (12.32 pm)-Born on 18 May 1920 and dying on 2 April 2005, Pope John Paul II was Pope of the Catholic Church for almost 27 years, the third longest reign in the history of the church. He oversaw a momentous period in world history, providing a moral force for his followers in the latter half of the 20th century as he travelled the globe, determined to reach as many people as possible, in the process becoming known as the ‘pilgrim Pope’. Pope John Paul II lent a spiritual force to his fellow Poles in the rise of the Solidarity movement, which went on to destroy a regime in the thrall of the communist ideology he so vehemently opposed. He also rallied against what he saw as the dangerously secular hedonism of the West, a spiritual malaise he saw as caused by an excessive adherence to materialism and consumerism. Unwavering in extolling his belief in the sanctity of human life-for example, in his vocal opposition to abortion, war and capital punishment-he nevertheless expressed traditional Catholic values in his attitudes towards marriage, sexuality and the role of women in the church. Pope John Paul II was unstinting in his advocacy of social justice and in the rights of the individual. Yet some of his views could be seen as challenging-some even divisive. As a student in southern Poland, Karol Wojtyla intended to become a professional actor. With the occupying Nazi regime closing the university he attended, and under threat of deportation, he was forced to support himself by working as a stonecutter. In 1942 he entered the underground seminary run by the Archbishop of Cracow and was ordained a priest in November 1946. In 1958 the future Pope was named Auxiliary Bishop of Cracow and four years later he assumed leadership of the diocese, all the while publicly rallying against communism and oppressive state officials and also secretly providing support-financial and otherwise-for opposition groups and, it is reported, often clandestinely meeting their leaders, who were on the run from the government. He was at the time the youngest bishop in Poland. In 1962 he contributed to the Second Vatican Council and within five years was elevated to cardinal. He refused to attend the First General Assembly of the Synod of Bishops due to a fellow Polish cardinal being denied a passport by the communist government. He participated in the papal conclave that elected Pope Paul VI and then, after the sudden death of Pope Paul VI’s successor, John Paul I, he found himself, a compromise candidate, at only 58 years of age, the 264th Pope of the Catholic Church. The new pope proved in the eyes of many, including the leader of the Solidarity movement, Lech Walesa, to be instrumental in the fall of communism in eastern Europe. His visits to Poland in 1979 and later in 1983 provided inspiration to the Catholic Church and to the growing non-violent Solidarity labour movement. In the words of future Polish communist leader Jaruzelski, his first visit was the ‘detonator’ for a train of events that eventually resulted in the collapse of the communist states in the East and the fall of the Iron Curtain. No less a person than Mikhail Gorbachev asserted that the disintegration of the Eastern bloc would have been impossible without Pope John Paul II. During his reign, Pope John Paul II became the most travelled pope in history, making more visits to foreign lands than all the previous popes combined. Many of these trips were to MAIN COMMITTEE the developing world and to countries never visited by a pope before, drawing some of the largest crowds in history. For instance, his visit to his Polish homeland in 1979 drew over two million people, while his mass in Dublin’s Phoenix Park in the same year drew one million people, a staggering one-quarter of the population of Ireland. He oversaw the global expansion of Catholicism, especially in Africa. His second visit to Nigeria saw the Pope canonize a Nigerian monk, greatly enhancing the Pope’s popularity in the region. Pope John Paul II was committed to spreading the influence of the church across the globe to Catholics and nonCatholics alike. I vividly remember his visit to Perth and our great family outing. We sat on a rug at the show grounds for many hours to attend mass there. Pope John Paul II, speaker of six languages, was determined to overcome religious divides, stressing the peace inherent in all religions. During his ceaseless travels he made several historical overtures to divergent faiths. He met with the Dalai Lama no fewer than eight times, finding common ground with a spiritual leader who had also suffered under communism. He was the first Catholic Pope to visit and pray in an Islamic mosque, and he subsequently visited the mosque where John the Baptist is understood to be buried. He was also the first pope to visit the United Kingdom, meeting the head of the Church of England, Queen Elizabeth II. In a powerful gesture at the time of the Falklands War, a battle he strongly spoke out against, he knelt to pray with the then Archbishop of Canterbury. However, despite significant stumbling blocks, it could be said that his greatest success was in bridging the divide between the Catholic and Jewish faiths, with a Jewish-American organisation declaring: ... more change for the better took place in his 27 year Papacy than in the nearly 2000 years before. Such approval stemmed from several actions undertaken by Pope John Paul II. He made a formal apology for the missteps committed by the Catholic Church over the last 2,000 years, expressly apologising for the acts of anti-Semitism committed by the church. He visited the Auschwitz concentration camp in his Polish homeland-the first pope to do so-and, in his historic visit to Israel in 2000, he left a written apology to the Jewish people in the Wailing Wall in Jerusalem. Furthermore, he issued an apology for the conspicuous silence that fell over the Catholic Church during the time of the Holocaust, and he became the first pope in modern times to visit a synagogue. Pope John Paul’s ecumenical efforts were instrumental in the emergence of a new, outward-looking Catholic Church. The Pope’s belief in the sanctity of human life expressed itself in his stance against contraception, euthanasia and abortion. Yet his belief in the rights and inherent dignity of the individual also manifested itself in his fervent opposition to war. To the Pope, all war was unjust and, in his words, a defeat for humanity. He asserted that all avenues must be exhausted before contemplating aggressive means, a position that logically led to his opposition to the war in Iraq. The Pope sent a cardinal from the Vatican to meet with the President of the United States to relay his opposition to the actions of the coalition of the willing, seeing any unilateral aggression as a breach of international law and seeing diplomacy through the United Nations as paramount. By speaking out almost daily on the injustice of the war, the Pope provided moral support to the millions of antiwar protesters throughout the world. This search for a political solution was emblematic of the Pope’s reign, with the Vatican sending diplomats to the Middle East, East Timor, the Balkans, Africa and Asia in the search for peace during intense periods of conflict. MAIN COMMITTEE The Pope’s influence was strongly felt in his shaping of the Catholic Church as a defender of human rights and of the poor and disenfranchised. He was a vocal supporter of Jubilee 2000, the campaign to provide debt relief to the beleaguered nations of Africa. He issued apologies for the suppression of ethnic and indigenous groups by past Catholic missionaries and was a strong supporter of the rights and aspirations of indigenous peoples, creating in 1992 a foundation for the indigenous peoples of Latin America to promote the development of rural communities among the campesinos of Latin America and the Caribbean and the African-American peoples. In a speech given here in Australia in Alice Springs in 1986, the Pope spoke compassionately and eloquently in support of the stolen generation and Aboriginal land rights. He said: Let it not be said that the fair and equitable recognition of Aboriginal rights to land is discrimination. To call for the acknowledgment of the land rights of people who have never surrendered those rights is not discrimination ... Christian people of good will are saddened to realise-many of them only recentlyfor how long a time Aboriginal people were transported from their homelands into small areas or reserves where families were broken up, tribes split apart, children orphaned and people forced to live like exiles in a foreign country. The establishment of a new society for Aboriginal people cannot go forward without just and mutually recognised agreements with regard to these human problems even though their causes lie in the past. If only such emphatic words were more prevalent today. The Pope decried the structural excesses of neo-liberalism and economic rationalisation, highlighting the devastating effect such policies have upon the poor and marginalised. As he stated, the wealth produced often remains in the hands of only a few. The Pope was a champion of workers’ rights. I have already touched upon his unwavering support of the Solidarity trade union in his homeland. In his encyclia the Pope affirmed the right of workers to join trade unions. In his 1981 statement, ‘On Human Work’, the Pope called for: ... ever new movements of solidarity of the workers and with the workers. This solidarity must be present whenever it is called for by the social degrading of the subject of work, by exploitation of the workers and by the growing areas of poverty and even hunger. The Pope continued by asserting the right of trade unions to exist and the right of workers: ... to form associations for the purpose of defending the vital interests of those employed in the various professions. These associations are called labor or trade unions... The experience of history teaches that organizations of this type are an indispensable element of social life. In another encyclical, Pope John Paul II reaffirmed the need for trade unions to: ... defend workers’ rights and protect their interests as persons while fulfilling a vital cultural role so as to enable workers to participate more fully and honorably in the life of their nation and to assist them along the path of development. Elsewhere he stressed the importance of a just wage, health care and workers compensation and the right to a retirement pension-all mainstays of the labour movement. The Pope’s compassion and sense of justice meant he instinctively sided with the workers. As progressives rightly point out, Pope John Paul II’s reign was not without fault. His views on contraception and the role of women in the church have been highly controversial, and he has rightly been admonished for his slow response to sexual abuse scandals within the church. Yet Pope John Paul II has had an extraordinary impact upon the Catholic Church and MAIN COMMITTEE hence upon the world, transforming the church under his charismatic leadership into an activist church based upon social justice, human rights and dignity and respect for the individual. A man of great integrity, compassion and conviction, his success was due to his ability as a world statesman to reach across to Catholics and non-Catholics alike. His words and actions during his 27-year reign will continue to reverberate. I wish to congratulate his successor, Benedict XVI, who, as confidante and right-hand man to the previous Pope, is no doubt aware of the great demands and requirements of the pontificate. I wish him well as he guides the Catholic Church into a new era. of other members of this parliament, to members of the Catholic Church, particularly the Catholic constituents of my electorate of Hinkler and the Catholics of the diocese of Rockhampton-notwithstanding the fact that I am a Catholic myself. I think John Paul II’s passing will be one of the seminal events of this new century that we live in because of the profound effect he had on so many lives. I wish to express my thanks for the life and work of John Paul II, Karol Wojtyla, who passed away on 2 April this year. He was truly a remarkable man. His 26-year papacy was marked by his drive to create a more inclusive church-one that extended the hand of friendship to all faiths-and by his truly global appeal as a man of the masses. He made his first communion at the age of nine and was confirmed at 18. When the Nazi occupation of his native Poland occurred, he had to work in a quarry from 1940 to 1944. No doubt it was in this environment that he developed his love for the workers of the world and for the unionists whom he served so well. He then worked in the Solvay chemical factory, to earn a living and to avoid deportation to Germany. In 1942 he became aware of his calling to the priesthood and started courses in a clandestine seminary in Cracow. After the Second World War he continued his studies at the major seminary in Cracow, being ordained there on 1 November 1946. His work took him to Rome and during his vacations he exercised his pastoral ministry amongst young Polish immigrants in France, Belgium and Holland. In 1948 he returned to Poland and until 1951 he was vicar of various parishes in Cracow and chaplain for the university students. Then he again took up studies in philosophy and theology. This led, 10 years later, to his being appointed the auxiliary bishop of Cracow by Pope Pius XII. He was consecrated on 28 September 1958. On 13 January 1964 he was nominated Archbishop of Cracow by Pope Paul VI, who made him a cardinal on 26 June 1967. His was a truly remarkable rise. In 1978 he became the 263rd successor to St Peter and the first non-Italian pope since Hadrian VI in 1522. John Paul II has a special place in history. He made the world’s business his business, especially in regard to human rights. Perhaps he will be best remembered for helping to deliver 400 million people from communist slavery. His profound effect on Eastern Europe was summarised by graffiti scrawled on one of the banners of the Polish communist state. The banner read, ‘The party is for the people.’ A courageous Pole had added to this banner, ‘But the people are for the pope.’ With his support of the free union movement Solidarity he not only created a new way of life for the working people of Poland and eventually all the people of Poland but also, through his influence-probably more than that of any other person in the 20th century-contributed to the breaking down of communism in other countries. It was not long after communism fell in Poland that other communist states fell like dominoes across MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Condolences

speaker: Mr Neville (Hinkler) (12.43 Pm)
theText: I rise to express my condolences, along with thoseEastern Europe, with East Germany and eventually Russia itself abandoning communism as a way of life. As a young Pole, John Paul II saw the Holocaust up close, and he grasped its radical significance for the church. He went on to make it his goal to heal the rift with Judaism, and this became a key element of his 26-year papacy. He apologised, as one of the previous speakers said, for the sins the church had committed against the Jewish people. His outreach involved ridding Christian education material of any anti-Semitic themes, visiting synagogues, pointing to the Holocaust as a permanent point of moral reckoning and reaffirming the rights of Jews to be at home in Israel-which the Vatican formally recognised as a state in 1994. No other pope travelled so widely and encountered so many individuals as John Paul II. He was estimated to have effectively circled the globe 27 times to deliver his message during his pontificate, including two visits to Australia. I can remember being in the grandstands of the QEII stadium in Brisbane, not long after the Olympic Games, and the tremendous atmosphere there. There was an Anglican or Lutheran pastor in front of me-I could not quite tell. I could see that he and his wife were tremendously moved by the fact that the Pope had come to Brisbane. During his 1986 visit, the Pope visited every state and territory and attended 38 functions in just 6½ days. One of the major events during that visit was a mass at Flemington Racecourse. John Paul II spoke directly to the young people of Australia, saying: Young people of Australia, I ask you: does your God have a part in your hopes and ambitions for the Australia of tomorrow? Do you dream of an Australia in which the poor and the downtrodden, the disadvantaged and the lonely, the spiritually blind and those struggling to make sense of their lives, will be sustained by the hands of a loving God? Do you realise that God has no other hands but yours to stretch out to those in need? What strong and lovely words to a young nation and to the young people of a young nation. I remember his second visit to Australia, in 1995, when he came here to beatify Mother Mary MacKillop. I remember a parliamentary debate not unlike this one. One of the members opposite would probably remember it, as would you, Mr Deputy Speaker McMullan. I think it was the longest debate on a private member’s business motion that we had ever had. Just about everyone in the parliament wanted to speak on it. It was about the beatification of Mary MacKillop. That was largely inspired and brought to its climax by the Pope’s visit to Australia. While most of his predecessors rarely ventured beyond the walls of the Holy See, John Paul II took the Catholic Church on the road, ministering to millions of the faithful, who were quite ecstatic in his presence. Interestingly, I met him quite by chance at the Vatican. I was there at the end of a parliamentary delegation trip and was on a private visit on the way home. Australia’s Deputy Ambassador to the Holy See was going to the Vatican that day and invited me to join him. The visit was very fulsome. The deputy ambassador took me through various parts of the Vatican. He showed me where the next consistory was going to be held-that new motel type facility-and took me up to meet some of the staff of the secretariat of state. There were no official tickets. I just happened to be behind the official enclosure. When the Pope had finished blessing the sick and saying the prayers he delivered that day, he went along the steps of St Peter and was photographed with the various official groups that were there. I think there was a band from Austria, and the University of Rome were there. MAIN COMMITTEE When he had finished, he was right at the edge of the steps of St Peter and he walked back down to a group of seminarians and across the enclosure where I was standing. I saw him look at his watch when I was about as far away as I am now from the opposition members. I said to my wife, ‘I think we’ve missed out.’ All of a sudden, he seemed to get another spurt of life and came down along the next row. That is how I met him. He certainly had an ecstatic presence; there is no doubt about that. In his travels around the world, he went to the church in Africa, Latin America and Asia, where the church was struggling in a different way from the West, where the church was struggling to maintain its flock and to maintain its focus on Christian values. He seemed to be able to stimulate each group in a different way. Around 18 million pilgrims participated in his general audiences, and this figure does not take into account the other, special audiences and religious ceremonies which he held. John Paul II met numerous government personalities during his 38 official visits, 738 audiences and meetings with heads of state, and 246 audiences and meetings with prime ministers-an extraordinary record. His desire for closeness with people almost led to his death, as is well recorded. In 1981 he was shot and seriously wounded by a Turkish fanatic in St Peter’s Square, but, more to the point, he forgave this man and frequently visited him in prison. The longevity of the Pope allowed him to appoint all but three of the 117 cardinals who were to choose his successor. The clarity that he left the church was, I think, an important feature in the quick decision of the cardinals to appoint Joseph Ratzinger as Benedict XVI. I, along with other members, extend my congratulations to Pope Benedict XVI. Probably the greatest legacy of Pope John Paul II-from my perspective, not from an international perspective-was the fact that he was a champion for the light, for decency and for high moral values, particularly in the great moral dilemmas of our time. He certainly copped a lot of criticism for his view on contraception, yet it was not based so much on an ideological, Catholic Church position as a consistency of view regarding the preservation of life. It did not extend just to contraception; it was equally forceful in the case of abortion, euthanasia and, more recently, stem cell research. The Pope spoke with a clarity that sometimes not all Catholics liked to agree with, but I think that, grudgingly, they knew he was right. I think that is one of the reasons why he had such a profound effect: he never varied from the truth. The religions of the world get into trouble when they start to play with the truth, when they alter things at the margins. We have seen that happen with a number of Christian churches in recent times. Pope John Paul II was the greatest pontiff of modern times. He was a warrior for freedom and human dignity and was a contemporary Catholic philosopher without peer. He was a pilgrim, a thinker and a man of peace. We were all diminished by his passing on 2 April but are the richer for his spirituality and his vision. Debate (on motion by Mr Quick) adjourned. Main Committee adjourned at 12.59 pm MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Condolences
